The job levels primarily require relevant experience, ability to use a keyboard, and in some cases, a valid driver's license. There is no specific mention of needing a higher educational degree as a qualification for the different levels of the support staff band positions. Instead, the emphasis is on skills, competencies, and experience in performing clerical and administrative functions.

The job specification focuses on experience in an office environment performing clerical and support services, keyboarding ability, and other specific competencies and tasks, rather than educational degree requirements.

name: Chief Inspector N J Racing Commission
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


CHIEF INSPECTOR, NEW RACING COMMISSION 53704

DEFINITION

Works under the direction of the Executive Director and the Assistant Secretary, represents the 
Commission at one of the tracks licensed by this agency. The Chief Inspector supervises the 
chemical testing inspectors, is charged with the responsibility of investigating complaints, inspects 
race track personnel, horses and procedures as related to New Jersey Racing Law and the 
Commission's Rules and Regulations governing thoroughbred and harness racing in New Jersey; 
does related work as required.

EXAMPLES OF WORK

Plans, organizes and supervises a staff engaged in the investigation of complaints involving the 
enforcement of New Jersey Racing Laws.

Plans, organizes and supervises a staff engaged in the inspection of the chemical analyses (blood, 
urine, saliva, etc.) of all horses participating on New Jersey race tracks.

Plans, organizes and supervises a staff engaged in the licensing of owners, drivers, trainers, stable 
names, partnerships, stable employees, platers and vendors who utilize New Jersey race tracks.

Supervises the maintenance of ledger receipt books; has responsibility of insuring all revenues are 
accounted for.

Plans, organizes and supervises a staff engaged in the licensing of all privately operated stable 
facilities located in New Jersey.

Supervises the issuance of official identification cards complete with photograph and fingerprint 
verification.

Receives and reviews laboratory chemical analysis test results made on racing entrants; when 
required, initiates official action based on the results.

Supervises the licensing of race track personnel involved in the pari-mutuel operations of the track.

Supervises the analysis of Daily Programs to insure that all persons, horses and organizations 
involved are duly and legally licensed.

Supervises the work operations and/or functional programs and has responsibility for effectively 
recommending the hiring, firing, promoting, demoting and/or disciplining of employees.

Periodically reviews assignments to insure prompt, expeditious handling of workload by Inspectors.

Reviews all inspection reports for accuracy and completeness and insures that they comply with all 
cross-checking procedures.

Assists the Secretary, Racing Commission, in the supervision of the filing and record systems and 
the procurement and control of supplies.

Instructs clerical and stenographic staff in the preparation of reports and correspondence.

Periodically confers with the Secretary, Racing Commission, regarding the effectiveness of 
operations within the Commission.

Participates in informal conferences.

Acts as a witness for the State in formal hearings or court proceedings.

Performs highly specialized inspections and/or investigations when required and reports thereon.

Assists in budget preparation.

Prepares weekly, monthly and annual reports of work progress, revenue progress and related 
matters to be submitted to the Secretary, Racing Commission, for review.

Maintains essential records, reports and files.

REQUIREMENTS 

EDUCATION

Graduation from an accredited college with Bachelor's degree.

EXPERIENCE 

Five years of experience as an inspector of personnel, horses and procedures at thoroughbred 
and harness racing tracks in New Jersey, one year of  which shall have been in a supervisory 
capacity.

Applicants who do not possess a college degree may substitute additional non-supervisory 
experience as described above on a year for year basis.

LICENSE 

Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of 
a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGES AND ABILITIES 

Thorough knowledge of the procedures and techniques useful in the investigation of complaints 
involving the enforcement of racing laws.

Thorough knowledge of the various problems likely to arise in the inspection of horses, race track 
personnel and procedures.

Thorough knowledge of training materials and techniques required for orientation and specialized 
training programs for the inspection staffs within the Commission.

Ability to analyze, or interpret and apply New Jersey Racing laws, rules, regulations, standards, 
policies and procedures to thoroughbred and harness racing in New Jersey.

Ability to organize assigned investigative work often of a technical and confidential nature, analyze 
the problems arising therein and develop appropriate work methods for Division investigative and 
other staff.

Ability to personally make special technical and confidential and sensitive investigations.

Ability to assign, instruct and supervise Commission inspection staff.

Ability to establish and maintain cooperative work relationships with local race track officials.

Ability to plan, organize and supervise the task force of inspectors engaged in inspection activities 

relating to thoroughbred and harness racing.

Ability to provide concise testimony in judicial proceedings.

Ability to present cases for prosecution at formal administrative hearings.

Ability to prepare and supervise the preparation of clear, sound, accurate and informative reports 
on investigative activities containing findings, conclusions and recommendations.

Ability to supervise the maintenance of essential reports, records and files in current condition.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English sufficiently to perform the 
duties of this position. American Sign Language or braille may also be considered as acceptable 
forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can perform the essential 
functions of the job after reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the 
accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such 
persons may not be eligible.

name: Chief Operating Engineer 2
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification



CHIEF OPERATING ENGINEER 2

DEFINITION:

Under the direction of an Engineer-in-Charge of Maintenance, a Business Manager, or other 
supervisory official in a State department, institution, or agency, has charge of the power and 
heating plant where capacity of the equipment involved is not less than 1000 and does not 
exceed 3000 boiler horsepower, and/or which may include major air conditioning units; 
supervises staff and work activities; prepares and signs official performance evaluations for 
subordinate staff; does other related duties as required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only.  A particular 
position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this job specification.  Conversely, 
all duties performed on the job may not be listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Plans the work program and work procedures, and analyzes power air conditioning and heating 
plant problems.

Assigns and instructs unit employees of varied classifications engaged in work relating to the 
operation and maintenance of boilers, engines, motors, steam absorption chillers, or centrifical 
chill pumps and auxiliary equipment, and supervises the performance of their work.

Plans the effective utilization of assigned personnel and available equipment, materials, and 
supplies.

Supervises the operation, adjustment, maintenance, and repair of varied types of generators, 
motors, compressors, feed and vacuum pumps, fuel oil pump and heater sets, feed conveyors, 
blowers, water softeners, combustion controls, automatic stokers, and other equipment.

Conducts periodic comprehensive tests and readings of boiler water treatment control, fuel 
consumption, pressure, draft conditions, temperature, and steam flow, using recording 
apparatus.

Inspects and checks safety units and devices.

Supervises the work involved in the operation, maintenance, and repair of refrigerating, 
ventilating, pumping, sewage, water, plumbing, and other auxiliary equipment.

Obtains, safeguards, stores, distributes, and supervises the proper use of needed equipment, 
materials, and supplies.

Prepares reports.

May be required to undergo fire-training classes.

Supervises the work operations and/or functional programs and has responsibility for effectively 
recommending the hiring, firing, promoting, demoting, and/or disciplining of employees. 

Maintains records and files of the unit.

Will be required to learn how to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and 
information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EXPERIENCE:
 
Four (4) years of experience in work involving the operation, maintenance, and emergency 
repair of power and heating plants and auxiliary equipment, one (1) year of which shall have 
been in a lead worker capacity.

LICENSE:

Appointees will be required to possess a minimum of a Stationary Engineer Second Class, 
Grade 1B (Red) License issued by the New Jersey Department of Labor and Workforce 
Development.

Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the 
operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential 
duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of the procedures and methods involved in the operation, maintenance, 
adjustment, and minor repair of varied types of feed and vacuum pumps, generators, 
and motors, feed conveyors, blowers, and automatic stokers.

Knowledge of the techniques used to conduct tests and readings of fuel consumption, 
pressures, draft conditions, temperature, and steam flow.

Knowledge of the procedures and methods used to inspect heating and power plants 
and auxiliary equipment.

Knowledge of the hazards and significant conditions to be encountered in the operation
and maintenance of a power and heating plant and equipment.

Knowledge of the methods used to lubricate and clean machinery and equipment.

Ability to supervise assigned staff and plan, organize, and implement projects within 
the unit. 

Ability to plan and supervise work involved in the operation, maintenance, and minor 
repair of varied types of pumps, generators, motors, feed conveyors, blowers, and 
automatic stokers.

Ability to conduct readings and comprehensive tests of fuel consumption, pressure, 
draft conditions, temperature, and steam flow.

Ability to inspect machinery and equipment, identify hazardous or significant conditions,
and determine the nature and extent of repairs.

Ability to obtain, store, safeguard, distribute, and supervise use of needed equipment, 
materials, and supplies.

Ability to prepare factual reports.

Ability to maintain essential records and files.

Ability to learn how to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and 
information systems used by agency, office, or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in English sufficiently to 
perform the duties of this position.  American Sign Language or Braille may also be 
considered as acceptable forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible if they can perform the essential 
functions of the job with or without reasonable accommodation.  If the accommodation 
cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such persons 
may not be eligible.

Additionally, specific licensing requirements, such as holding a Stationary Engineer Second Class, Grade 1B (Red) License, are necessary. The focus is more on practical experience and relevant certifications rather than formal higher education.

Additionally, a valid driver's license may be required if necessary for the position. There do not appear to be stated barriers to hiring an applicant without a college or university degree.

You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.





Job Specification



 
JUDICIARY OF THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY 
Administrative Professional Band Specification
Administrative Specialist Track
Financial Specialist Track
     
    BAND SUMMARY
Administrative Professionals perform payroll, benefits, classification, labor/employee relations, salary administration, recruitment, training, Equal Employment Opportunity, Affirmative Action, finance, accounting, purchasing, committee support, research, analysis, investigation, mediation, hearing and/or general support professional functions for the vicinages or central office. This band is separated into two tracks: administrative specialist and financial specialist.
LEVEL SUMMARY (BOTH TRACKS)
Level 1-Basic (Administrative Specialist 2 and Financial Specialist): Employees at this level perform entry-level professional administrative and/or financial functions.
Level 2-Journey (Administrative Specialist 3, Judiciary Coordinator 1, Financial Specialist 1 andLibrarian 1): Employees at this level perform more complex professional administrative and/or financial functions.
Level 3 - Mastery (Administrative Specialist 4, Judiciary Coordinator 2 and Financial Specialist 2): Employees at this level perform advanced professional administrative and/or financial functions. Assigned to act as mentor or lead worker, provide technical advice and expertise, and/or act as a subject matter expert. Employees at this level also may conduct formal hearings and/or mediation sessions.
NOTE: The above summary and following examples of work are for illustrative purposes only. Any one position may not necessarily include all of the tasks listed, nor do the examples cover all of the duties, which may be performed. Tasks are cumulative; higher levels include the tasks associated with the lower.
TASKS (BOTH TRACKS)
Level 1
Act as a liaison and/or establish working relationships with divisions, vicinages or other outside organizations
Act as staff to committees and/or conferences
Address community organizations, public forums, media or professional associations
Analyze requisitions, vouchers, bank statements or financial transactions
Answer questions posed by judges, the public, clients, customers, complainants, co-workers, subordinates or supervisors
Arrange training for staff or team members
Assemble materials
Attend and participate in meetings outside of work unit/team
Calculate salary data
Check written reports for completeness or and accuracy
Collect data
Collect and/or maintain case statistics or financial data to generate status reports
Compile records or other written materials
Compile statistical data on workload volume, backlog, unit expenditures, personnel actions, financial transactions, fixed assets, equipment or attendance
Complete subpoenas, writs, or other related legal documents
Coordinate and schedule meetings and other events based on availability
Coordinate report collection activities
Coordinate workflow between units or chambers
Design forms, newsletters, flyers, brochures, booklets, and other documents for publication
Determine status of complaints in accordance with established procedures or regulations
Develop manuals, guides, audio-visual aids or other materials
Develop block diagrams, flow charts, graphs or other illustrative presentations
Draft correspondence, reports or proposals
Enter items as credits or debits
Establish and/or maintain record keeping and/or tracking systems
Explain judiciary policies or procedures
Inform clients or customers of available agency support programs or services
Inform managers about employees’, clients’ or customers’ work progress or related matters
Interview clients or customers for needed information and document acquired information
Interview complainants and document acquired information
Interview job applicants
Monitor, screen, and prepare disbursements
Negotiate with vendors
Obtain books and periodicals
Operate audio or video equipment
Operate electronic or manual information systems
Participate in team development activities
Participate in team/work unit meetings
Plan agendas for meetings
Prepare and enter accounting entries
Proofread opinions, legal briefs or other written materials
Provide cross-training to co-workers; for example, demonstrate to other staff how you perform your work
Provide human resources support for unit or agency, such as classification, compensation, payroll, benefits, recruiting, selection or training/development
Provide information to judges, attorneys or community organizations
Provide quality customer service to court users and/or internal customers
Purchase commodities
Recommend changes to organizational structure
Recommend improvements in judiciary programs
Recommend improvements in operating procedures, programs, standards, work processes, or administrative practices
Recommend purchases of equipment, materials or supplies
Reconcile bank accounts
Refer individuals to appropriate federal, state, county or local agencies
Review clients' or customers' records 
Review court activities for compliance with procedures, laws, court rules, or administrative directives
Review vendor bids or product history for cost savings or award of contract
Schedule meetings, appointments, interviews and other activities necessary for accomplishing job assignments
Serve on committees or task forces
Suggest improvements in work unit operation
Tabulate accounting, financial, or statistical data
Upload, duplicate, reformat, or destroy standard media format files as instructed
Verify clients’ or customers’ information
Verify entered data against source documents
Write technical specifications for purchase of equipment, parts and supplies
Write user or operations documents or manuals
Level 2
Advise management or supervisors on personnel issues
Advise managers on deadlines, rules, regulations or related information
Analyze cases in accordance with existing laws, regulations or professional practices
Analyze programs or work units to determine effectiveness or efficiency
Analyze work processes or methods
Assist in negotiating labor contracts and bargaining unit agreements
Communicate policies, rules or regulations to staff or team members
Conduct classification analysis
Conduct financial audits for accuracy, compliance or legitimacy following standards to maintain security or confidentiality
Conduct investigations
Conduct quantitative or qualitative research of processes, programs or projects
Conduct training sessions or orientations programs
Coordinate and facilitate various programs and/or special projects
Coordinate production of video recordings
Coordinate with heads of internal or external units or community
Coordinate work activities of unit or team members
Develop operating budgets
Develop performance standards and content materials for use in program and performance evaluation
Establish workflow systems or procedures
Evaluate program, unit or team performance in accordance with established policies or procedures
Give advice or assist staff or team members with work in progress
Implement operating procedures or systems
Interpret accounting, financial or statistical data
Investigate complaints
Make recommendations and acquire books, periodicals, and other research materials
Maintain and reshelf books and publications
Monitor terms of services and/or conditions in compliance with court orders
Prepare proposal for solicitation of bids for purchases of commodities
Prepare technical, statistical, financial, review or evaluation reports
Provide structured training to co-workers
Provide technical direction and support on special video recording events such as high profile trials
Reconcile fixed assets to ensure compliance with established policies and procedures
Respond to attorney, litigant or citizen complaints
Select training materials and resource documentation for training programs
Update lists of current library holdings
Level 3
Act as hearing officer
Act as lead worker to team members or other group of non-subordinates in assigned tasks
Determine staff or team member training needs 
Develop administrative and/or internal control systems
Develop communications plans within or outside the organization or unit
Develop curriculums for training programs for large scale audiences
Develop policies or procedures to ensure efficient court or unit operations
Direct and/or coordinate work between units or teams
Establish accounting systems
Facilitate discussion among federal, state, vicinage, county or local officials
Formulate plans for utilization of available funds, personnel, equipment, materials, and supplies
Keep abreast of current trends, laws and rules
Mediate various legal matters
Mentor and coach staff or team members; provide direction and feedback
Plan implementation of projects or programs
Provide higher level technical advice and/or expertise to staff, peers or management
Resolve disputes, conflicts or problems regarding programs or services
COMPETENCIES (BOTH TRACKS)
NOTE: The following competencies are cumulative in nature. For example, lower level competencies are prerequisite to higher levels.
Level 1
 Contracting and Procurement - Knowledge of various types of contracts and techniques for procurement.
Customer Service - Committed to providing quality services. Commands a thorough understanding of the customer, who he or she is, why and what he or she wants and needs. Focuses work on meeting and exceeding the customer’s needs. Develops and maintains strong relationships with internal and external customers, vendors or suppliers. Builds customer confidence in the ability to serve their needs.
Economics, Finance and Accounting - Knowledge of economic, financial and accounting principles and practices and the analysis of reporting financial data.
Human Resources - Knowledge of various personnel practices and procedures.
Information Management - Identifies a need for and knows where or how to gather information. Organizes and maintains information or information management systems.
Integrity and Honesty - Contributes to maintaining the integrity of the organization. Displays high standards of ethical conduct and understands the organization’s standards, including confidentiality in court operations, when appropriate, and the impact of violating these standards on the organization, self and others. Trustworthy.
Interpersonal Skills - Shows understanding, respect, collegiality, courtesy, tact, empathy, cooperation, concern, and politeness to others. Develops and maintains effective relationships with others; including effectively dealing with individuals who are difficult, hostile, or distressed. Relates well with people from varied backgrounds and different situations. Sensitive to cultural diversity, race, gender, disabilities, and other individual differences. Participates fully in team activities.
Legal/Government - Knowledge of laws, legal codes, legal documents, government regulations, executive orders, agency rules, New Jersey Rules of Court, government organization and functions.
Mathematical Reasoning - Performs computations, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication and division correctly using whole numbers, fractions, decimals and percentages. Solves practical problems by applying a variety of mathematical and statistical techniques.
Negotiating - Works with others towards an agreement.
Oral Communication - Effectively communicates information, for example, ideas or facts, to individuals or groups effectively, taking into account the audience and nature of the information, for example, technical, sensitive, controversial. Makes clear and convincing oral presentations. Listens to others, attends to nonverbal cues, and responds appropriately.
Organizational Awareness - Knows the organization’s mission and functions, and how its social, political, and technological systems work, and operates effectively within them, including the programs, policies, procedures, rules, and regulations of the organization.
Personal Development - Identifies and follows through on assignments, guidance and feedback to continuously learn and improve the performance and capabilities of one’s self.
Reading Comprehension - Understands and interprets written material; including technical material, rules, regulations, instructions, reports, charts, graphs or tables. Applies what is learned from written material to specific situations.
Reasoning - Identifies rules, principles or relationships that explain facts, data or other information. Asks pertinent questions to acquire needed information. Analyzes information and makes logical inferences or draws accurate conclusions.
Self-Management - Sets well-defined and realistic personal goal. Displays a high level of initiative, effort, and commitment towards completing assignments in a timely manner. Works with minimal supervision. Motivated to achieve. Demonstrates responsible behavior.
Stress Tolerance - Deals calmly and effectively with high stress situations, for example, tight deadlines, hostile individuals, emergency situations, dangerous situations.
Teamwork - Encourages and facilitates cooperation, pride, trust, and group identity. Fosters commitment and team spirit. Works with others to achieve goals.
Technical Competence - Uses knowledge that is acquired through formal training and/or extensive on-the-job experience to perform one’s job. 
Time Management - Establishes and manages priorities effectively. 
Total Quality Management - Shows attention to detail, accuracy and thoroughness. Committed to quality and excellence. Finds the root cause of problems. Looks for and makes continuous improvements. Follows through on implementing improvements and commitments made to others.
Written Communication - Composes correspondence, reports and other written material that is clear, concise, well organized and understood by recipient. Recognizes and uses correct English grammar, punctuation, and spelling. Communicates information, for example, facts, ideas, or messages, in a succinct and organized manner. Produces written information which may include technical material that is appropriate for the intended audience.
Level 2
Auditing - Knowledge of generally accepted auditing standards and procedures for conducting financial, compliance, economy and efficiency, and program results audits.
Contracting and Procurement - Knowledge of various types of contracts, techniques for contracting and/or procurement and contract negotiation and administration.
Decisiveness - Makes sound and well informed decisions. Perceives the impact and implications of decisions. Commits to action.
Financial Management - Plans, administers and monitors expenditures to ensure cost effective support of programs and policies.
Goal Orientation - Budgets time. Adjusts priorities in ways that meet optimal conditions. Manages multiple projects, priorities and deadlines.
Human Resources - Knowledge of hiring, classification, benefits, labor relations, negotiations and federal, state and local employment regulations.
Laws/Rules/Policies/Procedures - Interprets, understands, applies and complies with laws, rules, policies and procedures. Demonstrates familiarity with organizations policies/procedures and relevant laws and rules in human resources and management administration. Demonstrates familiarity with laws and rules related to critical finance, accounting, purchasing, training, labor/employee relations, EEO/AA, benefits law, job analysis, salary administration, selection, bargaining unit contract application and payroll administration. 
Negotiating - Negotiates to find mutually acceptable solutions.
Planning and Evaluating - Organizes work, sets priorities and determines resource requirements. Determines short or long term goals and strategies to achieve them. Coordinates with other organizations or parts of the organization to accomplish goals. Monitors progress and evaluates outcomes.
Professional Development - Keeps up-to-date on best practices available in the profession and attempts to implement those appropriate to the organization’s needs.
Teaches Others - Helps others learn through formal or informal methods. Identifies training needs. Provides constructive feedback. Coaches others on how to perform tasks. 
Technical Application - Uses machines, tools or equipment effectively. Uses computers and computer applications to analyze and communicate information in the appropriate format.
Level 3
Conflict Management - Manages and resolves conflicts, confrontations, and disagreements in a positive manner which minimizes negative impact.
Conflict Resolution - Reconciles, negotiates and mediates conflicts and/or grievances to acceptable solutions.
Cost - Keeps cost of achieving goals to a minimum. Sensitive to cost related issues. Maintains work within budgetary guidelines.
Counseling – Mentors, guides and coaches staff or team members. Provides feedback targeted at individual development.
Creative Thinking - Develops new insights into situations and applies innovative solutions to effectuate improvements or resolve problems. Designs new strategies as necessary where established methods and procedures are inapplicable, ineffective, inefficient, or unavailable.
Decision Making - Makes sound, well-informed and objective decisions. Perceives the impact and implications of decisions. Commits to action, even in uncertain situations, to accomplish organizational goals. Recommends, devises, and/or implements change. Effectively deals with ambiguity.
Financial Management - Prepares, justifies and/or administers the budget for program areas. Assesses financial condition of an organization.
Flexibility - Open to change and new information. Adapts behavior or work methods in response to new information, changing conditions, or unexpected obstacles.
Interpretation and Analysis of Written Materials - Comprehends and evaluates information, balancing the pros and cons to determine a desired outcome. Makes recommendations based upon logic or acquired knowledge. 
Leadership - Influences, motivates and challenges others. Adapts leadership styles to a variety of situations.
Visualization - Mentally organizes and processes symbols, pictures, graphs, objects or other information, for example, visualizes a building from a blueprint or visualizes the flow of work activities from reading a work plan.
Persuasion - Develops and articulates well thought out arguments to inform and persuade the decision maker where appropriate.
MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS
ADMINISTRATIVE TRACK
(Administrative Specialist 2, Administrative Specialist 3, Administrative Specialist 4,
Judiciary Coordinator 1, Judiciary Coordinator 2, and Librarian 1)
Education
Levels 1, 2 and 3:

For Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree in behavioral or social science, as specified in the Domestic Violence Hearing Officer Program Standards.


For custody, visitation, Children in Court Mediator positions*: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a graduate degree or certification of advanced training in a behavioral or social science and completion of a recognized mediation training program consisting of 40 hours of instruction.


For all other positions: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree.

Experience
Level 2
Three years of professional experience in the area of specialty specific to the job function being performed (see areas listed below).
Level 3:

For Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Five years of professional experience including three years of experience in the areas of domestic violence or family crisis.


For custody, visitation, children in court Mediator positions*: Four years of professional experience in one or more of the following areas: mediation, counseling, family intake, crisis intervention, custody/visitation dispute investigations and/or child support. This professional experience shall have included supervised clinical experience in mediation.


For all other Administrative Track Level 3 positions: Five years of professional experience in the area of specialty specific to the job function being performed (see areas listed below).

Levels 1, 2 and 3 Areas of Specialty:

Program Evaluation: program development, program coordination, program analysis, program administration and/or administrative research


Administrative Operations: purchasing, facilities management, operations management, records retention, transcript services, jury management, statistical reporting, investigations and/or library administration


Human Resources: payroll processing, benefits administration, salary administration, classification, labor/employee relations, training, selection/recruitment and/or Equal Employment Opportunity/Affirmative Action

Substitution

For custody, visitation, Children in Court Mediator positions*: At the discretion of the Assignment Judge relevant experience may be substituted for either the graduate degree or clinical experience, or both.


For all other Administrative Track Level 1, 2 and 3 positions except Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Applicants who do not possess the required education may substitute additional paraprofessional and/or professional experience on a year-for-year basis with one year of such experience being equal to 30 semester hour credits. An associate’s degree from an accredited college or university and two years of additional paraprofessional and/or professional experience may be substituted for a bachelor’s degree.

Note

For custody, visitation, Children in Court Mediator positions*: In: In special circumstances and at the request of the Assignment Judge, the Administrative Office of the Courts may temporarily approve for a one year period an applicant who has not yet completed the specialized family mediation training, provided the applicant has at least three years of experience as a Mediator or a combination of mediation experience and service in Family Part, has co-mediated in a CDR program with an experienced family mediator, and certifies to the intention to complete the specialized training within one year following the temporary approval.

Levels 2 and 3 (except Mediator positions)
A master’s degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for one year of experience.
Levels 2 and 3 (except Domestic Violence Hearing Officer and Mediator positions)
A law degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for two years of experience.

For Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Admission to the NJ Bar and one year of experience in family law, which shall include work involving domestic violence, may be substituted for one year of the required experience.

NoteNote: A master’s degree or a law degree from an accredited college or university, may be used as a substitution, not both. 
FINANCIAL TRACK
(Financial Specialist, Financial Specialist 1 and Financial Specialist 2)
Education
Levels 1, 2 and 3
Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree including or supplemented by 21 credit hours in accounting, business administration, economics, public administration and/or finance. Twelve of these credit hours must be in accounting.
Experience
Level 2 (Financial Specialist 1)
Three years of professional accounting, finance, auditing and/or budgeting experience.
Level 3 (Financial Specialist 2)
FiveFive years of professional accounting, finance, auditing and/or budgeting experience.
Substitution
All Levels
Applicants who do not possess the required education, but do possess the 21 accounting, business administration, economics, public administration, and/or finance credit hours, including 12 accounting credit hours, may substitute additional paraprofessional and/or professional experience on a year-for-year basis with one year of such experience being equal to 30 semester hour credits. 
Levels 2 and 3
A master’s degree from an accredited college or university in business or public administration, economics, accounting or finance may be substituted for one year of general experience -OR- a CPA designation may be substituted for one year of general experience as indicated above.
License
Appointees will be required to possess a driver’s license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelorâs degree.
A masterâs degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for one year of experience.
A law degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for two years of experience.

alternativeQualifications: paraprofessional and/or professional experience on a year-for-year basis
associate's degree and additional experience

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: Based on the job description provided, a higher educational degree is required for this job. For positions in the administrative track (excluding specific roles like Domestic Violence Hearing Officer and Mediator), a bachelor's degree is generally required. Additionally, experience is essential, and the degree requirements can sometimes be substituted with additional professional experience, as outlined in the job specification. Similarly, for financial track positions, a bachelor's degree with specified credit hours in accounting-related fields is necessary, although there are provisions for substituting this educational requirement with equivalent professional experience. Furthermore, for higher-level positions, a master's degree or a law degree can substitute for some years of required experience, indicating the importance of higher education for certain roles within this job framework.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driverâs license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants:
The job description outlines several barriers for applicants who do not have a college or university degree:

1. For most positions, a bachelor's degree is required, particularly in specified areas such as behavioral or social science for Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions and custody, visitation, Children in Court Mediator positions. 

2. For financial track positions, graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelorâs degree, supplemented by specific credit hours in accounting and related fields, is required.

3. Substitutions are allowed for some positions, but they still rely on a combination of education and extensive professional experience, such as an associateâs degree combined with additional professional experience or specific credit hour requirements in related fields.

4. Advanced degrees such as a masterâs degree or a law degree can substitute for experience but are not a substitute for the educational requirement entirely.

5. For mediator positions, specific training and certification requirements are stated, which implies additional barriers for those without formal education credentials.

6. A requirement to possess certain credit hours in specific fields (for financial positions) also constitutes a barrier to those who may not have attended college.

Overall, the job description heavily emphasizes formal education, particularly a bachelor's degree, as a prerequisite for various roles across both tracks, creating a barrier for applicants without such credentials.

name: Residential Living Specialist
text:
Job Specification 04138D 











	
		
	    
	
	
		
			
				
					
				   
				
		  
	  
	
	
		 
	
	
		You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
	
	
		
	
	
		
	  
	
	
		
  
    
Job Specification 04138D 

RESIDENTIAL LIVING SPECIALIST (MENTAL HEALTH/DEAF LANGUAGE: SPECIALIST)

 

DEFINITION


 Under  direction of a supervisory official in a hospital, school,
 or  institution,  provides direct services for mentally  disabled
 hearing  impaired residents in areas of direct   care,  training,
 providing   meals,   recreation,  education,  social   education,
 vocational  education, and direct and  indirect services  in  the
 areas   of  sanitation  and  cleaning,  laundry,  and  supportive
 programming, on grounds and in  community activities; does  other
 related duties as required.

 NOTE: The  examples of work for this title are for illustrative
 purposes  only.  A particular position using this title  may  not
 perform all duties listed in this job specification.  Conversely,
 all duties performed on the job may not be listed.

 
EXAMPLES OF WORK:


 These  examples  of  work are to be performed  by  utilizing  the
 language of the deaf, particularly American Sign Language.

 Assumes  responsibility for physical, mental, and emotional  well
 being  of  residents  assigned  to  his/her  care  and  reinforce
 treatment team efforts to establish adequate communications  with
 hearing impaired clients.

 Maintains a continuous resident training program in a residential
 setting  with  particular  emphasis on self  help  and,  whenever
 possible,  social development to limit of  individual  resident's
 ability.

 Trains  and assists residents to function more independently  and
 to  develop  skills in bathing, dressing, combing hair,  trimming
 nails,  brushing  teeth,  shaving,  and  giving  whatever   other
 assistance is required by residents to ensure adequate  standards
 of personal hygiene.

 Prepares and serves meals to residents and feeds those unable  to
 help  themselves. Trains residents to prepare,  serve,  and  feed
 themselves where applicable.

 Instructs residents in proper use of eating utensils.

 Prepares food for use in cooking process; as assigned, may assume
 responsibility for certain phases of the preparation and  cooking
 process;  instructs residents in these activities (food purchase,
 preparation,   storage,  menu  planning,  and  so  forth)   where
 appropriate.

 Serves   food  from  steam  tables  where  necessary;   arranges,
 prepares,  and  serves  food  trays  when  required;  supervises,
 assists,   and  instructs  residents  in  performance  of   these
 functions.

 Prepares and instructs residents in preparation of foods, salads,
 beverages, and desserts as required.

 Sets   tables,   changes  linens,  counts  dishes,   linen,   and
 silverware, and trains residents in performance of these tasks.

 Inventories  all  supplies  and  monitors  equipment   within   a
 residence.

 Washes  dishes,  pots,  and  pans,  silverware,  and  other  food
 preparation equipment, and instructs residents in proper and safe
 techniques of performing these duties.

 Polishes  and washes various cooking and food preparation  items,
 for example, milk containers, roasters, broilers, silverware, and
 so  forth,  and  instructs residents regarding  proper  and  safe
 methods of performing these tasks.

 Positions and places orthopedic hearing aides and support devices
 on  residents and instructs residents to do this themselves where
 possible.

 Aids  in  development  of  and  maintains  an  active  recreation
 program,  and  participates  in  outdoor  and  indoor  recreation
 activities with residents both on grounds and in community.

 Sees  that  proper measures are taken at all times  to  eliminate
 actual  or  potential  hazards  to  safety  and  well  being   of
 residents.

 Ensures  that  special  safety devices for the  hearing  impaired
 residents  are  kept  in good working order  and  their  use  and
 warning systems are understood by all residents/clients.

 Sees  that order is maintained among residents in unit and refers
 unusual   or  serious  behavior/disciplinary  problems   to   the
 appropriate supervisor.

 Escorts  residents,  when appropriate, to  treatment  facilities,
 church services, recreation or work areas, or any other locations
 that might be required.

 Aids   nursing  staff  with  simplified  treatments  and  changes
 dressings as directed.

 Lifts residents onto and off of beds and stretchers, or into  and
 out of wheelchairs as needed.

 As  a member of a treatment team, provides input into development
 of Individual Treatment Plans for the residents assigned.

 Participates   in  therapeutic  treatment  activities   such   as
 community  meetings, small groups, one-to-one activities  and  so
 forth.

 Performs  housekeeping  activities  and,  where  needed,  trains,
 assists, and/or supervises clients in performance of all types of
 housekeeping activities including bed making, mopping,  sweeping,
 and  scrubbing  of walls and floors, waxing floors,  cleaning  of
 living  quarters, lavatories and fixtures, eating areas; dusting,
 waxing and polishing furniture; collecting and properly disposing
 of  waste  papers,  trash  and other  refuse,  cleaning  windows,
 screens,  shades  and blinds, vacuuming carpets, replacing  light
 bulbs  and  fuses, maintaining running inventories and sufficient
 stock  of housekeeping supplies, for example, soap, toilet paper,
 towels, cleaning solutions, and so forth.

 Operates and trains residents in operation of dishwasher,  irons,
 vacuum  cleaners, scrubber, and similar equipment  necessary  for
 upkeep of physical plant, furniture, and fixtures.

 Sees  that residents are properly dressed and that their clothing
 is  cleaned  and  repaired as needed; sorts, and counts  laundry,
 properly  storing  that which has been cleaned;  washes  clothes,
 towels,   and  flatware  as  required  and  in  accordance   with
 manufacturer's  care  label  instructions.  Trains  and   assists
 residents to perform these tasks where needed.

 Serves  special  diets  in  accord  with  prescribed  instruction
 regarding portion control and types of food.

 Maintains  a sanitary and healthful environment within residence;
 keeps  residence  neat  and clean, free of garbage  and  clutter.
 Stores  perishable food in covered containers (labeled and dated)
 under refrigeration, and discards it at appropriate time.

 Checks daily to ensure that refrigerator is clean and functioning
 at proper temperature.
 Participates in inservice training and continuing education.

 Prepares factual reports.

 Organizes work and develops effective work methods.

 Keeps  required  records  with accuracy  and  with  attention  to
 detail.

 Will  be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic
 and/or  manual  recording  and information  system  used  by  the
 agency, office, or related units.

 REQUIREMENTS:

      EXPERIENCE:
 Two  (2)  years of experience in the direct care of the  mentally
 disturbed, hearing impaired in either a residential or  community
 setting  or  other  setting providing care  to  hearing  impaired
 persons.

      SPECIAL SKILL
 Applicants must be able to communicate effectively in the language of
 the  deaf,  particularly American Sign Language, sufficiently  to
 perform the duties of this position.

      SPECIAL NOTE: Appointees for Marie H. Katzenbach School  for
 the  Deaf must successfully pass a screening process administered
 by the school=s Deaf and Hard of Hearing Committee.

      LICENSE:
 Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New
 Jersey  only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than  employee
 mobility,  is  necessary to perform the essential duties  of  the
 position.

 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Knowledge of communications systems employed by hearing  impaired
 persons.

 Knowledge  of physical, mental, and emotional needs  of  mentally
 disturbed  persons,  and of procedures and  methods  required  to
 provide for such needs.

 Knowledge of techniques used in training individuals with varying
 degrees  of mental disability and/or physical handicaps in  areas
 of  self  care  and  socially  accepted  behavior  to  limits  of
 individual's potential.

 Knowledge of clients rights.

 Knowledge of preparation of food for cooking.

 Knowledge  of  proper  methods and materials  used  in  cleaning,
 polishing, and in maintaining kitchen, storage, and food  service
 areas in a clean, sanitary, orderly, and safe condition.

 Knowledge  of problems and methods of inspecting and  determining
 when  cleaning and maintenance work should be done and  materials
 needed.

 Knowledge  of  problems  encountered and  materials,  tools,  and
 procedures  used  in  washing, waxing, vacuuming,  and  polishing
 wood,  tile,  cement,  linoleum, and other floors  and  woodwork,
 furniture, and fixtures.
 Knowledge of proper use and minor adjustment of sweepers,  vacuum
 cleaners, floor waxers and polishers, and other equipment.

 Ability to communicate and relate to hearing impaired persons  in
 daily living experience.

 Ability  to  organize  assigned cottage  training  work,  analyze
 problems, and develop appropriate work methods.

 Ability  to  relate to cottage residents in a manner  which  will
 encourage their cooperation and potential development.

 Ability to perform uncomplicated subprofessional nursing care  or
 other special care prescribed for individual residents.

 Ability  to provide positive therapeutic support through  use  of
 communication skills.

 Ability  to  assist  with and participate in outdoor  and  indoor
 recreation activities.

 Ability to bathe, dress, and provide other assistance required by
 residents to maintain established standards of personal hygiene.

 Ability to feed residents who present serious feeding problems.

 Ability  to  properly  lift  and  handle  residents  with  severe
 physical handicaps.

 Ability  to understand, remember, and carry out oral and  written
 instructions  and  assignments,  and  to  organize  work  in   an
 efficient manner.

 Ability to work effectively with associates, superiors, families,
 and residents.

 Ability  to  serve  food  from steam  tables  or  other  utensils
 efficiently.

 Ability to appropriately prepare and serve food.

 Ability to wait on tables and to deliver trays.

 Ability  to  perform  and take lead in manual  work  involved  in
 washing dishes, pots and pans, in polishing silverware and  metal
 equipment,  in  keeping ranges, and broiler, roaster,  and  other
 equipment clean and polished, and to scrub and wax floors, halls,
 and other areas.

 Ability  to operate and supervise operation of laundry equipment,
 including washers and tumblers.

 Ability  to  keep an assigned unit or area in a clean,  sanitary,
 and orderly condition.

 Ability  to obtain, store, safeguard, and properly use equipment,
 materials, and supplies.

 Ability to observe safety precautions and to recognize and report
 potentially hazardous conditions.

 Ability   to  select  and  use  appropriate  washing  soaps   and
 detergents, bleaches, rinses, and water temperatures for specific
 types of laundry.

 Ability  to  instruct  clients in inspecting,  working,  sorting,
 checking, folding, and distribution of laundry.

 Ability to prepare accurate factual reports.
 Ability  to  utilize  various types of electronic  and/or  manual
 recording  and  information systems used by  agency,  office,  or
 related units.

 Ability  to  read, write, speak, understand, and  communicate  in
 English   sufficiently  to  perform  duties  of  this   position.
 American  Sign  Language or Braille may  also  be  considered  as
 acceptable forms of communication.

 Ability to communicate in sign language and AMSLAN.

 Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long
 as  they  can  perform  essential  functions  of  the  job  after
 reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations.   If
 the  accommodation  cannot be made because  it  would  cause  the
 employer undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

 CODES: 14/H14-04138D           CAH                9/12/98

alternativeQualifications: Two (2) years of experience in direct care of the mentally disturbed, hearing impaired in either a residential or community setting or other setting providing care to hearing impaired persons.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for this job. The job primarily requires two years of experience in the direct care of the mentally disturbed, hearing impaired individuals. Additionally, candidates must be able to communicate effectively in American Sign Language to perform the duties of the position. There is no explicit mention of a higher educational degree in the job requirements, suggesting that relevant experience and skills with sign language are more critical qualifications for this role.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description does not explicitly list a college or university degree as a requirement, so there are no direct barriers mentioned regarding educational qualifications for hiring an applicant who does not have a degree. The focus is on experience and skills, particularly in American Sign Language and experience in the direct care of mentally disturbed, hearing-impaired individuals.

name: Chief Special Populations And Activities Addictions
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


CHIEF, SPECIAL POPULATIONS AND ACTIVITIES, ADDICTIONS

  DEFINITION

 Under direction of an Assistant Commissioner or other supervisory
 official, provides leadership in establishing policies, goals,
 and objectives in public and/or private treatment programs
 designed to prevent, treat, and rehabilitate persons designated
 as special populations with alcohol, drug abuse, or other
 addiction problems; does other related duties.

 NOTE: The examples of work for this title are for illustrative
 purposes only.  A particular position using this title may not
 perform all duties listed in this job specification.  Conversely,
 all duties performed on the job may not be listed.
 
 EXAMPLES OF WORK:

 Serves as ombudsman for all clients' needs and treatments
 (clients are considered a special population in that they are
 classified as disabled by federal regulations).

 May act as principal advisor to the Assistant Commissioner in 
 the area of special population needs.

 May provide staff services and consultation to the Assistant
 Commissioner relative to long-range and operational planning,
 analytical, and evaluation activities related to special
 populations.

 Plans, coordinates, and supervises program activities.

 Develops and organizes criteria and administrative policies
 designed to achieve division goals related to special
 populations.

 Evaluates program plans and objectives to determine their
 effectiveness and appropriate utilization for the needs of
 designated special populations.

 Conducts and/or coordinates need studies for special populations.

 Provides recommendations.

 Supervises training sessions.

 Provides advice and technical assistance for special projects and
 populations for community, state, and federal programs.

 Supervises the work operations and/or functional programs and has
 responsibility for effectively recommending the hiring, firing,
 promoting, demoting, and/or disciplining of employees.

 Meets with representatives of community groups and organizations.

 Establishes liaison and maintains cooperative working
 relationships with other organizations and offices to provide
 care and treatment for those individuals designated as special
 populations.

 Develops budgetary needs of the unit.

 Develops plans to meet federal or state guidelines, and funding
 sources, or projects appropriate to meet needs of the client or
 staff populations..

 Prepares correspondence.
 Prepares clear, sound, accurate, and informative statistical and
 other related reports containing findings, conclusions, and
 recommendations.

 Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic
 and/or manual recording and computerized information systems used
 by the agency, office, or related units.

 REQUIREMENTS:

      EDUCATION:

      Graduation from an accredited college or university with a
 Bachelor's degree in Sociology, Psychology, Social Work, or other
 related field.

      EXPERIENCE:

      Four (4) years of administrative experience in planning,
 developing, and supervising coordinated treatment and
 rehabilitation services in the area of psychosocial disorders
 which shall have included drug abuse or other addictions, two (2)
 years of which must include working specifically with the unique
 needs of special populations.

      NOTE: A Master's degree in one of the above educational
 areas may be substituted for one (1) year of indicated
 experience.

      LICENSE:

      Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license
 valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather
 than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential
 duties of the position.

 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Knowledge of management principles, and techniques.

 Knowledge of program planning and development techniques.

 Knowledge of the problems encountered by those suffering from
 substance abuse.

 Knowledge of the methods used to detect, treat and prevent
 substance abuse.

 Ability to plan, initiate, and execute programs.

 Ability to analyze, interpret, and apply basic laws, rules, and
 regulations.

 Ability to maintain cooperative working relationships with
 associates and subordinates, and other divisions, departments,
 and/or branches of government and the public.

 Ability to assign, instruct, and supervise professional and other
 staff.

 Ability to plan, conduct, and supervise investigations, surveys,
 studies, and research activities.

 Ability to prepare clear, sound, accurate, and informative
 reports containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations.

 Ability to supervise the maintenance of records and files.

 Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or
 manual recording and information systems used by the agency,
 office, or related units.

 Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in
 English sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.
 American Sign Language or Braille may also be considered as
 acceptable forms of communication.

 Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as
 long as they can perform the essential functions of the job after
 reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations.  
 If the accommodation cannot be made because it would cause 
 the employer undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor's degree in Sociology, Psychology, Social Work, or other related field.
A Master's degree in one of the above educational areas may be substituted for one (1) year of indicated experience.

alternativeQualifications: Four (4) years of administrative experience in planning, developing, and supervising coordinated treatment and rehabilitation services in the area of psychosocial disorders

mandatoryStatusExplanations.bothTrueExplanation: The job description specifies that a Bachelor's degree in Sociology, Psychology, Social Work, or a related field is required, which indicates that a degree is mandatory for the position. Additionally, it does allow for a Master's degree in one of the specified educational areas to substitute for one year of the required experience, but it does not indicate that any alternative qualifications can replace the degree itself. Therefore, both conditions are met as the degree is clearly requisite without mention of alternative qualifications.
mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is required for this job. The job description specifies that candidates must have a Bachelor's degree in Sociology, Psychology, Social Work, or a related field. Additionally, it notes that a Master's degree in the specified educational areas may substitute for one year of required experience, indicating the importance of formal education in this role. The role also requires specific administrative experience, knowledge, and abilities related to planning and supervising programs for special populations with addiction issues. Therefore, a higher educational degree is seen as essential to possess the knowledge and capabilities necessary for the position.
