This constitutes a barrier for applicants who do not have a college or university degree.

name: Secretary Board Of Public Utilities
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SECRETARY, BOARD OF PUBLIC UTILITIES 56675

DEFINITION

In conformity with New Jersey Statute N.J.S.A. 48:2-4, the Board of Public Utility Commissioners 
shall appoint a Secretary whose statutory duties shall be as follows: "The Secretary or in his/her 
absence an Assistant Secretary shall keep full and correct minutes of all the transactions and 
proceedings of the Board and perform the other duties required of the position. He/she shall be the 
official reporter of the proceedings of the Board".

The Secretary also coordinates the utility customer complaint resolution process; coordinates and 
supervises case management; coordinates and supervises Word Processing Center; responsible 
for reviewing all Board orders and official correspondence for both technical and legal sufficiency; 
along with technical staff, is responsible for planning decisions and actions and board present and 
future policy; the Secretary shall perform any other duties prescribed by the Commissioners; does 
related work as required.

EXAMPLES OF WORK

Has a statutory duty to keep a true and accurate record of all Board proceedings.

Serves at all Board meetings as the official reporter.

Establishes the date for all Board hearings. Prepares and disseminates legal public notices of all 
Board proceedings in compliance with the Administrative Procedure Act, N.J.S.A. 52:14B-1 et. 
seq.

Receives and processes all applications, petitions, motions and other pertinent legal memoranda 
filed by the industries the Board regulates; interested local, State and federal governmental 
agencies, including but not limited to the Division of Rate Counsel, Department of the Public 
Advocate, the Department of Law and Public Safety, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, 
and both the State and Federal Departments of Energy; and the public.

Informs all interested parties of the final decisions of the Board on all rate cases, motions, and 
other notifications the Board requires.

Processes all cases transmitted by the Board to the Office of Administrative Law.

Receives and distributes to agency representatives all Initial Decisions received by the Board and 
assures that the Board acts upon such Initial Decisions within the time limitations prescribed by law.

Reviews for legal and technical sufficiency all public documents issued by the Board including but 
riot limited to Board Orders, official letters and notices of disposition of motions.

Reviews and issues decisions, orders, subpoenas, and other legal documents as directed by the 
Board.

Coordinates the prompt distribution of and responds to all correspondence received by the Board 
to assure that the concerns raised by the public are acted upon and answered within the scope of 
the Board's statutory and regulatory power.

Prepares, updates and. publishes the Agenda of the Board's weekly public meeting, assuring 
complete technical and legal analysis are presented for proper Board review.

Supervises and manages the Board's Bureau of Customer Assistance.

Engages and assists in resolving customer-utility complaints through informal negotiations or 
through formal settlement conferences.

Coordinates Board customer complaint staff with Board technical staff in order to resolve 
complicated technical customer complaints.

Develops rules and regulations regulating the safe and adequate provision of electric, gas, water, 
solid waste, telephone and cable television utility services in New Jersey.

Prepares and formulates utility customer outreach programs.

Directs the formatting, printing and mailing of all Board decisions, orders and official documents 
through supervision of the Board's Central Word Processing Unit.

Directs the classifying, filing maintenance of 411 closed and pending cases at the Board through 
the Board's Document and File Center.

Supervises the Board's Computerized Case Management System to assure that all case records 
are kept up-to-date and complete.

Formulates policy and procedures for the conduct of pre-transmittal conferences.

Supervises and manages the case pre-transmittal conferences prior to transmittal by the Board to 
the Office of Administrative Law as contested cases, assuring that all relevant factual and legal 
issues are developed and/or stipulated prior to hearing.

Coordinates all scheduled pre-transmittal conferences designed to settle issues and/or cases of 
any petitions pending before the Board.

Coordinates the activities of the Citizens Advisory Board which provides the Board with public 
input on pressing public utility matters.

Establishes and designs a Code of Ethics for Board employees to be approved by the Board of 
Public Utilities and the New Jersey Commission of Ethical Standards.

Attends and testifies at Legislative Committee Hearings on pending legislation affecting or 
modifying the statutory responsibilities of the Board.

Supervises the work operations and/or functional programs and has responsibility for employee 
evaluations and for effectively recommending the hiring, firing, promoting, demoting and/or 
disciplining of employees.

Personally inspects the facilities and observes the operation of utilities in the State when so 
required by difficult and complex problems and attends consumer conferences throughout the State.

Prepares or directs the preparation of appropriate comprehensive formal reports and memoranda 
on various subjects for the review of the Board.

Advises the Board with respect to various statutes, including the Administrative Procedures Act 
and the Open Public Meetings Act as they apply to formal public meetings of the Board of Public 
Utility Commissioners.

Formulates, supervises and coordinates training programs for all persons who conduct formal 
hearings and investigations on behalf of the Board.

Performs such other functions and duties as may be assigned by the Board.

Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and information 
systems used by the agency, office or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English sufficiently to perform the 
duties of this position. American Sign Language or braille may also be considered as acceptable 
forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can perform the essential 
functions of the job after reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the 
accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such 
persons may not be eligible.


This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote56675SUNL98N/AX98-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 10/17/86

mandatoryStatusExplanations.bothFalseExplanation: The job description for the Secretary, Board of Public Utilities, does not specify a requirement for a degree, nor does it mention any alternative qualifications. The focus is on statutory duties, responsibilities, and various skills such as managing, coordinating, and advising. Since no educational qualifications are listed, it indicates that a degree is not mandatory. Similarly, the job description does not provide any alternative qualifications or equivalent experience requirements, leading to the conclusion that neither is expressly needed.
mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not explicitly required for the position of Secretary, Board of Public Utilities, as detailed in the job description. The job requires significant responsibilities, such as managing legal documents, coordinating customer complaints, supervising units, and understanding complex legal and technical matters. While the position does not stipulate a degree requirement, it implies the need for skills and knowledge that might typically be acquired through higher education, experience in legal or regulatory environments, or professional experience in utility management. Therefore, while not absolutely required, a higher educational degree or equivalent professional experience would likely be beneficial for this role.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description does not explicitly state any educational requirements or a requirement for a college or university degree. However, it involves complex duties such as supervising case management, reviewing legal documents for technical and legal sufficiency, preparing comprehensive formal reports, advising on various statutes, and coordinating policy and training programs. These duties may implicitly suggest a preference for candidates with a higher education background, possibly in law, public administration, or a related field, which could pose a barrier for applicants without a college or university degree.

name: Senior Traffic Investigator
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SENIOR TRAFFIC INVESTIGATOR	
		                                                  
DEFINITION:

Under the limited supervision of a Principal Traffic Investigator or other 
supervisory official in the Department of Transportation, performs designated 
field investigations, surveys, and other related office work and acts as a lead 
worker in a traffic investigator team; does other related duties as required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only.  
A particular position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this 
job specification.  Conversely, all duties performed on the job may not be 
listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Takes the lead in a group of Traffic Investigators involved in the conduct of 
field investigations 
relating to proposed traffic control plans submitted by municipal governments.

Assists in the review of proposed traffic ordinances to determine their 
conformity to sound traffic planning principles.

Reviews reports and recommendations of the traffic investigations staff for 
completeness and 
accuracy, as may be required.

Conducts field investigations of traffic conditions, including those pertaining 
to the more complex traffic programs as required.

Conducts investigations of the efficacy of operation of the several types of 
traffic regulatory and control methods and devices; makes reasonable and 
feasible recommendations concerning their improvement, continued used, 
or discontinuance.

May be required to work with State and local  government officials toward 
the alleviation of traffic problems.

Prepares clear, sound, accurate, and informative statistical and other reports
of traffic conditions, problems, and plans containing findings, conclusions, and 
recommendations. 

Maintains essential records and files.

Will be required to learn how to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual
recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EXPERIENCE:

Three (3) years of experience in the area of traffic regulations, traffic investigation,
and/or traffic control.

LICENSE: 

Appointees will be required to possess a driverï¿½s license valid in New Jersey 
only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary 
to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of traffic regulation and control problems.

Knowledge of the varied types of devices, equipment, and methods used in 
traffic regulation and control systems and their advantages and limitations 
under varying conditions.

Knowledge of the techniques used to conduct traffic investigations, surveys, 
and studies, including studies of speed, driver behavior, parking, and other 
related studies.

Knowledge of the equipment, devices, and procedures used in performing 
traffic investigations, surveys, and studies, including studies of speed, driver 
behavior, parking, and other related studies.

Knowledge of the New Jersey State Highway System with emphasis upon 
traffic regulation and traffic control problems.

Knowledge of the standards established for traffic control devices as set forth 
in the Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways Manual.

Knowledge of the purposes, policies, procedures, and standards of the d
epartment regarding traffic regulation and control.

Knowledge of those portions of Title 39 of the New Jersey Revised Statutes 
and FHWA policies and procedures dealing with traffic regulations.

Knowledge of statistical mathematics, methods, and procedures.

Ability to understand, analyze, and apply the New Jersey laws and the rules, 
regulations, policies, procedures, and standards of the Department of 
Transportation pertaining to traffic control and regulation.

Ability to comprehend traffic control and regulatory problems in New Jersey.

Ability to evaluate the suitability, advantages, and limitations of existing and/or 
proposed traffic control and regulatory devices, equipment, systems, and 
procedures regarding their practicality and feasibility for specific situations.

Ability to conduct field visits, inspections, surveys, and studies involved in the
investigation and analysis of traffic regulation and control problems.

Ability to prepare clear, technically sound, accurate, and informative statistical 
and other reports of traffic control and regulation problems.

Ability to maintain essential records and files.

Ability to learn how to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording 
and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in English sufficiently 
to perform the duties of this position.  American Sign Language or Braille may 
also be considered as acceptable forms of communications.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible if they can perform the 
essential functions of the job with or without reasonable accommodation.  If the 
accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue 
hardship, such persons may not be eligible.


This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote11233SC4015N/AI16-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 7/04/2020

alternativeQualifications: Three (3) years of experience in the area of traffic regulations, traffic investigation, and/or traffic control

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for the Senior Traffic Investigator job according to the job description provided. The requirements specified include three years of experience in traffic regulations, investigation, and/or control, but there is no mention of a requirement for a specific degree. The focus appears to be on practical experience and knowledge of traffic control and regulatory issues, as well as the ability to perform the duties listed, rather than on formal education credentials.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driverâs license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description for the Senior Traffic Investigator position does not explicitly state a requirement for a college or university degree, nor does it suggest such a requirement. However, there is no mention of alternative pathways or explicit acknowledgment that equivalent experience could substitute for a degree. The requirement of at least three years of experience in traffic regulations, investigation, or control may pose an indirect barrier for those who have gained relevant skills through non-traditional means but do not have formal experience or education in these areas.

name: Sign Maker 2
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SIGN MAKER 2

DEFINITION

A position in this job category in a state agency or a local jurisdiction, typically
designs sign layout and lettering from wood, plastic or reflective metal; draws
graphic material or lettering for title, backgrounds or other layouts; operates
lettering equipment and tools; sets up sign fabrication equipment; and provides
technical advice to staff, peers or management.

NOTE: The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only. A
particular position using this title may not perform all the duties listed in the job
specification. Conversely, all duties performed on the job may not be listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK

Designs sign layout and lettering from wood, plastic or reflective metal.

Distributes materials, equipment, parts or supplies.

Reads journals or other publications for the purpose of keeping abreast of
developments in the field.

Draws graphic material or lettering for title, backgrounds, or other layouts.

Records the use of materials, equipment, parts or supplies.

Estimates necessary quantity of time, costs, materials or personnel for the
accomplishment of assignments or goals.

Proofreads material for accuracy.

Verifies that quantity and type of item ordered matches invoice.

Computes numerical data by addition, subtraction, division and multiplication.

Designs layouts of graphic or printed materials.

Recommends the purchase of new and replacement materials, equipment, parts
and supplies.

Obtains current price quotes for special purchases.

Operates lettering equipment and tools.

Sets up sign fabrication equipment.

Cuts adhesive reflective sheet from roll.

Applies detail, background, and shading to signs.

Cleans tools and work areas.

Cuts stencils.

Applies press type or other transfer lettering materials.

Operates power saws and drill press.

Sends (dispatches) materials and equipment to construction sites.

Cuts metal.

Marks outline of sign on glass with pounce pattern.

Arranges perishable stock by date received.

Consults with outside agencies or individuals about information for job
assignments.

Provides technical advice to staff, peers and management.

Answers questions about application of regulations or policies

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual
recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS

	EDUCATION

	Completion of a vocational, technical or specialized training program in
	graphic arts, graphic and printing communications, or graphic arts
	technology.

	EXPERIENCE

	Two (2) years of experience in work involving sign design, layout, and
	lettering, or graphic arts

	NOTE:  Applicants who do not possess the required education may
	substitute one (1) year of additional experience as described above. .

	LICENSE

	Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in NJ only if
	the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to
	perform essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of lettering techniques and their application.

Knowledge of techniques for applying commercial lettering to layout design.

Knowledge of the principles and techniques of copy preparation, composition and
layout.

Knowledge of the techniques of screen printing.

Knowledge of layout techniques.

Knowledge of procedures for cleaning tools and work area.

Knowledge of general vocabulary and spelling.

Knowledge of metal cutting techniques and equipment.

Knowledge of the use of drafting instruments.

Ability to make precise measurements for graphic designs.

Ability to operate lettering equipment and tools.

Ability to apply lettering techniques to art projects.

Ability to use layout equipment and tools.

Ability to follow oral orders, written orders, directions and plans.

Ability to keep accurate records.

Ability to operate power saw.

Ability to operate drill press.

Ability to read and interpret laws, rules and regulations.

Ability to convey information in a written format.

Ability to add, subtract, multiply and divide, using decimals, percentages and
fractions.

Ability to comprehend, interpret and evaluate relevant information from various
types of source materials.

Ability to operate spray gun.

Ability to establish goals and set priorities.

Ability to compare written or printed material for accuracy.

Ability to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and
information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in English sufficiently
to perform duties of this position.  American Sign Language or Braille may also
be considered as acceptable forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can
perform essential functions of the job after reasonable accommodation is made to
their known limitations.  If the accommodation cannot be made because it would
cause the employer undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote03705CC401315C14-This job specification is for state and local government use.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 10/30/2004

alternativeQualifications: One (1) year of additional experience in work involving sign design, layout, and lettering, or graphic arts

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for this job. The position requires the completion of a vocational, technical, or specialized training program in graphic arts, graphic and printing communications, or graphic arts technology. Alternatively, applicants may substitute one year of additional relevant experience for the educational requirement. The emphasis is placed on practical experience in sign design, layout, and lettering, or graphic arts, suggesting that hands-on skills and experience are prioritized over formal higher education.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in NJ only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.
professionalLicenseRequirement.issuingAuthority: DMV or equivalent agency in NJ

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description for the Sign Maker 2 position requires the completion of a vocational, technical, or specialized training program in graphic arts, graphic and printing communications, or graphic arts technology. However, this education requirement can be substituted with one additional year of relevant experience. Therefore, lacking a formal degree might be a barrier unless the applicant has extra relevant work experience to substitute for the education requirement.

name: Sign Technician Trainee
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SIGN TECHNICIAN TRAINEE

DEFINITION:

Under the close supervision of a Crew Supervisor, Signs in the 
Department of Transportation, as a trainee and productive worker, 
receives on-the-job training in the fabrication, reconditioning, 
installation, replacement, and repair of highway signs, including 
sign support structures for various types of highway signs; learns 
how to operate, adjust, and maintain necessary
equipment; does other related duties as required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes 
only.  A particular position using this title may not perform all duties 
listed in this job specification.  Conversely, all duties performed on 
the job may not be listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Receives on-the-job training in the installation, maintenance, and 
repair of highway signs, sign structures, and the equipment and 
machinery required for the fabrication of highway traffic signs.

Learns to lay out various signs for the application of electronically 
cut reflective letters, backgrounds, and/or die stamped metal letters.

Learns to operate and maintain the machinery necessary to cut 
and apply reflective letters and backgrounds. 

Learns to operate hydraulic power sheers to cut materials to the 
appropriate size.

Learns proper safety and operation of a plasma cutter.

Learns to enlarge scale-sized drawings from the Standard 
Highway Signs Manual. 

Learns to operate and maintain the equipment used in the screen 
printing of signs; mixes inks to the proper consistency for screen 
process printing.

Learns to fabricate silk screens and cut screen stencils by hand 
from several types of stencil film.

Learns to fabricate vinyl banners.

Learns to spray-paint various types of surfaces.

Learns to maintain the shop, tools, and equipment in an orderly 
and safe condition.

Learns to work from heights up to 75 feet from an aerial platform 
truck or similar equipment. 

Learns to repair, replace, and install signs and sign support 
structures, and assist in the performance of priority repairs.

Learns to drive automobiles, trucks, or other equipment as required.

Learns to maintain records of work completed and materials used.

Learns to operate and maintain the computer assisted and electronic 
sign making equipment used in the design of signs.

Performs snow removal and ice control work at any time of day 
or night as required.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or 
manual recording and information systems used by the agency, 
office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EDUCATION:

Appointees must successfully complete the following training within 
one (1) year of appointment:

     ï¿½	Work Zone Safety
     ï¿½	Blood Borne Pathogen/Poisonous Plants
     ï¿½	Hazardous Material Handling
     ï¿½	Driver Awareness
     ï¿½	Basic Snow Fighter
     ï¿½	Communications/Two-way Radio
     ï¿½	Identifying Roadway Sign Damage
     ï¿½	Qualified Person Training
     ï¿½	Boom Truck Operation and Safety
     ï¿½	Industrial Crane and Rigging

LICENSE AND CERTIFICATION:

Appointees will be required to obtain and maintain a current certification 
as a Powered Industrial Truck Operator issued by the New Jersey 
Department of Transportation within the first twelve (12) months after 
appointment to the title, or possess a current Coaching the Lift Truck 
Operator 2 certification or its equivalent.

Appointees must obtain a Commercial Driverï¿½s License (CDL) and 
applicable endorsements for the class and type of vehicle being 
operated within the first six (6) months after appointment to the title.

NOTE:  The responsibility for ensuring that employees possess the 
required motor vehicle license, commensurate with the class and 
type of vehicles they operate, and the Powered Industrial Truck 
Operator certification, Coaching the Lift Truck Operator 2 certification, 
or an equivalent certification, rests with the Appointing Authority.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of the use of basic hand tools, including power actuated 
and pneumatic tools.

Knowledge of taking measurements and utilization of measuring 
devices.

Ability to learn screen process printing techniques.

Ability to understand and apply appropriate safety precautions, 
especially work zone safety measures.

Ability to learn the methods, materials, and techniques used to lay 
out traffic and highway signs.

Ability to learn to cut screen stencils by hand.

Ability to learn to operate and maintain tools, equipment, and 
machinery used for the large-scale production of signs and repair 
of sign support structures.

Ability to learn to work from an aerial platform truck or similar 
equipment, up to a height of 75 feet.  

Ability to learn to fabricate, erect, and recondition signs, support 
structures, and effect repairs.

Ability to learn to mix and thin inks for screen process printing.

Ability to learn to maintain records.

Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual 
recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or 
related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English 
sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.  American Sign 
Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of 
communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as 
they can perform essential functions of the job with or without 
reasonable accommodation.  If the accommodation cannot be made 
because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such persons 
may not be eligible.

ADVANCEMENT:

Appointees who successfully complete the twelve (12) month trainee 
period, including the required training units and obtaining the required 
CDL license with the applicable endorsements for the class and type 
of vehicle being operated within six (6) months of appointment and 
a certification as a Powered Industrial Truck operator within twelve 
(12) months of appointment (if the employee does not already 
possess a Coaching the Lift Truck Operator 2 certification or an 
equivalent certification), will be eligible for advancement to the title 
Sign Technician 1.

The inability of an employee in this title to obtain a CDL license 
and applicable endorsements for the class and type of vehicle being 
operated within six (6) months of appointment and a certification as 
a Powered Industrial Truck operator within twelve (12) months of 
appointment (if the employee does not already possess a Coaching 
the Lift Truck Operator 2 certification or an equivalent certification), 
to complete the required training period, and/or to attain a level of 
performance warranting advancement to the Sign Technician 1 title, 
shall be considered a cause for separation.
This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote42052SN4095N/AC95-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 9/15/2018

The focus is primarily on receiving on-the-job training and successfully completing specific training courses and certifications within certain time frames after appointment. Additionally, required skills and abilities listed are all learnable through training rather than requiring prior degree-level education. Therefore, a degree is not mandatory for this job, and there is no mention of any alternative qualifications related to formal education degrees that could substitute for any required degrees.

The job description emphasizes on-the-job training for various skills related to sign fabrication, installation, and maintenance. It requires the completion of specific safety and operational training within one year of appointment, obtaining necessary certifications related to equipment operation, and acquiring a Commercial Driverâs License within the first six months. The focus is on learning practical skills and safety procedures rather than requiring formal educational qualifications.

Instead, it focuses on on-the-job training and specific certifications related to the role. Therefore, there are no stated barriers in the job description for hiring an applicant without a college or university degree.

name: Principal Railroad Inspector
text:
Job Specification 14844 











	
		
	    
	
	
		
			
				
					
				   
				
		  
	  
	
	
		 
	
	
		You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
	
	
		
	
	
		
	  
	
	
		
  
    
Job Specification 14844 

PRINCIPAL RAILROAD INSPECTOR

 

DEFINITION


 Under direction of supervisory official in the Department of
 Transportation, supervises work of railroad inspectors and senior
 railroad inspectors assigned to the investigation of railroad
 operations, the inspection of locomotives and equipment, and/or the
 inspection of construction work at railroad grade crossing elimination
 projects; is responsible for traffic counts and surveys at allocated
 areas; does other related duties as required.

 NOTE: The examples of work for this title are for illustrative
 purposes only. A particular position using this title may not perform
 all duties listed in this job specification. Conversely, all duties
 performed on the job may not be listed.

 
EXAMPLES OF WORK:


 Supervises and instructs employees engaged in inspection and
 investigation work.

 Inspects and/or supervises the inspection of existing or proposed
 railroad highway crossings at grade to ascertain their condition and
 methods of protection.

 Inspects and supervises the inspection work performed by railroad
 companies or construction firms relative to the elimination of
 railroad highway grade crossings, and advises on methods of inspecting
 materials and construction of such projects to ensure adherence to
 plans and specifications.

 Conducts research to solve problems arising in connection with grade
 separation projects.

 Supervises and participates in passenger counts on trains, traffic
 counts at railroad highway crossings at grade, and inspections of
 passenger stations and train equipment.

 Supervises and conducts investigations of accidents on railroad
 property or at grade crossings to determine causes and to develop
 recommendations for corrective action to prevent reoccurrence of such
 accidents.

 Supervises the compilation and preparation of data pertaining to
 discontinuance or curtailment of train schedules, changes of station
 status or services, and abandonment of railroad lines.

 Prepares reports.

 Maintains files.

 Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic
 and/or manual recording and information systems used by the agency,
 office, or related units.

 REQUIREMENTS:

      EXPERIENCE:

      Three (3) years of experience in the investigation and/or
 inspection of railroad facilities and equipment and railroad grade
 crossings, structures, and/or services or operations; or in the
 inspection and recording of mechanical and/or electrical inspections;
 or the inspection and recording of mechanical and electrical railroad
 equipment, (1) year of which shall have been a supervisory capacity.

      LICENSE:

      Appointees will be required to posses a driver's license valid in
 New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee
 mobility, is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Knowledge of regulations, policies, purposes, standards, and
 procedures of the department after a period of training.

 Knowledge of regulations, policies, purposes, standards, and
 procedures of the Interstate Commerce Commission as relevant to
 railroad operations and services.

 Knowledge of state and federal laws governing operation of railroads
 and established standards of safety of operation for railroad
 facilities and equipment.

 Knowledge of railroad operations including practices and procedures
 used by railroads in plotting train schedules, and of records kept by
 railroads concerning train performance and passenger loads.

 Knowledge of methods of inspection used to determine compliance with
 plans and specifications for construction of grade crossings and
 installation of grade crossing warning devices.

 Knowledge of rail equipment and repair shop producers.

 Knowledge of standards for equipment, maintenance, and housekeeping of
 railroad stations.

 Ability to note and appraise significant facts and conditions in
 investigations of railroad facilities and to draw conclusions.

 Ability to prepare reports.

 Ability to maintain files.

 Ability to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording
 and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

 Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in English
 sufficiently to perform duties of this position. American Sign
 Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of
 communication.

 Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as
 they can perform essential functions of the job after reasonable
 accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the accommodation
 cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship,
 such persons may not be eligible.

 CODES: 19/R20 - 14844           RKR/cah                     1/6/98

alternativeQualifications: Three (3) years of experience in the investigation and/or inspection of railroad facilities and equipment and railroad grade crossings, structures, and/or services or operations; or in the inspection and recording of mechanical and/or electrical inspections; or the inspection and recording of mechanical and electrical railroad equipment, with one (1) year of supervisory capacity.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: The job description for the Principal Railroad Inspector position in the State of New Jersey does not specify a requirement for a higher educational degree. Instead, the requirements focus on specific experience related to the inspection and investigation of railroad facilities and equipment. Specifically, three years of relevant experience, including one year in a supervisory capacity, is required. Additionally, knowledge of relevant regulations and the ability to perform specific duties related to inspections are necessary. Therefore, a higher educational degree is not explicitly required for this job, as the emphasis is on practical experience and specific skills.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to posses a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description does not explicitly state a requirement for a college or university degree, so there is no direct barrier related to educational qualifications for applicants without a degree. The primary requirement is three years of relevant experience, with at least one year in a supervisory capacity.

name: Technical Assistant 3
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


TECHNICAL ASSISTANT 3						

DEFINITION

Under the general supervision of a supervisory official in a State 
department, institution, or agency, takes the lead over the technical and/or 
clerical staff and has responsibility for the work programs of an identifiable 
technical unit responsible for reviewing, monitoring, and processing specific 
actions requiring the application  of rules, regulations, policies and/or 
procedures, or independently, under general supervision, reviews, analyzes, 
and makes effective recommendations for actions involving a specific 
element of a regulatory or administrative program requiring the application of 
rules, regulations, policies, procedures, and/or technical concepts; does other 
related duties as required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only.  
A particular position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this 
job specification.  Conversely, all duties performed on the job may not be 
listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Takes the lead in overseeing assignments and guiding technical and/or 
clerical employees of varied grades, and reviews their work.

Takes the lead in reviewing complex, irregular, and sensitive actions; when 
errors are discovered, makes required corrections and/or recommendations.

May review and verify the completed actions of the unit.

May analyze and interpret new regulations and policies as they affect 
the processing of actions and sees that these are put into practice.

Provides recommendations in developing and evaluating methods for 
reducing the workload at the clerical and/or para-professional level 
without sacrificing efficiency and essential information.

Prepares routine correspondence and form letters that may or may not 
be signed by a supervisory official.

May research funding sources, assist in the development and review of 
grant applications, and write proposals.

May prepare and execute contracts for funding within various programs.

May provide oversight of payments, initiate payment activities, monitor 
processing of payments to ensure accuracy, and resolve payment 
processing problems. 

Oversees the maintenance of the unit's specialized and general files.

May provide procedural information, obligations, responsibilities, and rights 
to program participants and other interested parties.

May serve as the unit liaison to gather and disseminate information, and 
address problems.

Makes specialized technical determinations, within the scope of authority, 
regarding specific program actions.

Independently researches the feasibility of new program areas, involving data 
gathering, survey techniques, and preparing recommendations on project 
proposals.

May assist in the planning, coordinating, implementing, and upgrading existing 
programs in an assigned area.

Reviews completed cases prior to submission for payment to include 
re-certifications, budget revisions, and interim redeterminations.

Maintains an automated data processing tracking and information system to 
ensure efficient flow of actions.  

Reviews requested actions to ensure that all necessary technical information 
is correct and appropriate.

Works with the submitting agency to correct deficiencies and function as a 
representative of their department/institution/agency.

May contribute to developing and implementing financial systems in order 
to improve budgetary procedures and internal fiscal control procedures.

Cooperates and communicates with staff, and monitors production and 
program activities to ensure goals are met and maintained.

May monitor socially oriented programs designed to meet the needs of state 
and/or local public and private agencies.

Coordinates, gathers, compiles, assembles, analyzes, and interprets data 
required by the supervisory official and/or professional staff in completing 
assigned tasks.

Responds to requests for information, providing technical and procedural 
information to agencies and individuals concerning the assigned program.

May assist in planning and conducting program outreach and promotional 
activities.

Assists in resolving technical problems and complaints within the scope of 
authority.

Provides technical assistance to all staff members in matters of mutual 
interests.

Takes the lead in preparing and verifying statistical, technical, or financial 
reports that are clear, technically sound, comprehensive, and accurate.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual 
recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EDUCATION:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with an Associate's degree.

NOTE:  Applicants who do not possess the required education may substitute 
additional experience as indicated on a year-for-year basis with thirty (30) 
semester hour credits being equal to one (1) year of experience.

EXPERIENCE:

Three (3) years of experience in providing support to functions such as 
grant/contract compliance monitoring, program monitoring, or fiscal compliance 
and budgetary assistance and/or providing technical assistance to state and/or 
local communities or agencies, completing forms or applications, reviewing 
documents for accuracy and content, resolving complaints, or interpreting rules, 
regulations, policies, and procedures for the public and/or others.

NOTE:  Applicants who do not possess the required experience may substitute 
additional education as indicated on a year-for-year basis with thirty (30) 
semester hour credits being equal to one (1) year of experience.

LICENSE:

Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey 
only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary 
to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of office methods, practices, routines, machines, and equipment.

Knowledge of the problems encountered while coordinating the collecting, 
appraising, and interpreting of data.

Knowledge of the problems encountered in planning a large-scale clerical 
program, in organizing assigned clerical and technical work, and in developing 
effective work procedures in a technical field.

Knowledge of the methods used to collect and analyze data.

Ability to prepare, analyze, and audit financial documents and contracts.

Ability to organize assigned technical and/or other work, analyze the problems 
that arise, and develop effective work methods.

Ability to assist in the planning, coordinating, implementing, and upgrading 
existing programs in an assigned area.

Ability to conduct surveys, independent research, and field investigations.

Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with others.

Ability to take the lead in overseeing assignments and giving instructions to 
technical and/or clerical employees, and review the performance of their work.

Ability to comprehend, analyze, interpret, and apply basic laws and regulations 
in accordance with established procedures and policies.

Ability to do research which will support the development of program proposals.

Ability to assist in reviewing grant applications and writing program proposals.

Ability to review programs using federal and state funds and to assist in 
formulating and recommending corrective actions where deficiencies exist.

Ability to take the lead over a specialized unit of technical work, devise 
appropriate schedules and routines, and provide for emergency and peak 
load periods.

Ability to resolve complaints involving independent decision making, based 
upon rules and regulations.

Ability to interpret basic laws, regulations, policies, procedures, and methods 
to persons within or outside of the department.

Ability to prepare and supervise the compilation of material for and the 
preparation of suitable bulletins, pamphlets, and circulars of varied types.

Ability to prepare detailed, technical, and confidential correspondence, as 
may be required for the signature of a supervisory official.

Ability to prepare and verify statistical, budgetary, and other reports containing 
findings, conclusions, and recommendations.

Ability to maintain essential records, reports, and files.

Ability to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and 
information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in English 
sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.  American Sign Language 
or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can 
perform essential functions of the job with or without reasonable accommodation.  
If the accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the employer 
undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with an Associate's degree.

alternativeQualifications: Three (3) years of experience in providing support to functions such as grant/contract compliance monitoring, program monitoring, or fiscal compliance and budgetary assistance and/or providing technical assistance to state and/or local communities or agencies

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for the Technical Assistant 3 position as stated in the job description. The requirements specify an Associate's degree, but they also allow for the substitution of experience on a year-for-year basis, with 30 semester hour credits equating to one year of experience. This implies that individuals without an Associate's degree may qualify if they possess the necessary experience in providing support related to grant/contract compliance monitoring, program monitoring, or fiscal and budgetary assistance. Therefore, practical experience can compensate for the lack of a formal educational degree in this case.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description specifies a requirement for graduation from an accredited college or university with an Associate's degree. However, it provides an option for applicants who do not possess the required education to substitute additional experience on a year-for-year basis, with thirty semester hour credits being equal to one year of experience. This presents a barrier initially due to the degree requirement, but the allowance for experience as a substitute provides a way for applicants without a formal degree to still qualify for the position.

name: Dispute Resolution Specialist 1

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Possession of a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university
Possession of a Master's degree from an accredited college or university in Dispute/Conflict Resolution
Possession of a Juris Doctor's degree

alternativeQualifications: Six (6) years of professional experience in mediating litigation and public disputes and/or facilitating the development of new rules or policies through consensus building.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for the position of Dispute Resolution Specialist 1. The job description allows for different pathways to fulfill the experience requirements, including six years of professional experience in relevant areas, or a combination of a bachelor's degree and two years of experience. Additionally, a Master's degree in Dispute/Conflict Resolution with one year of experience, or a Juris Doctor's degree, could also qualify an applicant for this position. This indicates that while higher education can be beneficial and offers alternative pathways, extensive relevant professional experience can also suffice to meet the job requirements.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description presents a barrier for applicants without a college or university degree, as it explicitly states that applicants must either have relevant professional experience or possess a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university. This requirement implies that applicants without a degree must have significant documented experience in the specified field to be considered, potentially limiting opportunities for those who may have gained relevant skills through non-traditional or experiential pathways.

name: Director Of Appellate Practices And Labor Relations
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


DIRECTOR OF APPELLATE PRACTICE AND LABOR RELATIONS

DEFINITION

Under the direction of the President of the Civil Service Commission, assists in the formulation of 
policies and procedures of the Commission and the Department; plans, organizes and directs the 
work programs, activities and staff of the Division of Administrative Practices and Labor Relations, 
represents the President in all matters relating to labor relations; does related work as required.

EXAMPLES OF WORK

Under the direction of the President of the Civil Service Commission:

Drafts, coordinates, supervises and oversees all rules, regulations and orders that may be required 
to implement the statutory authority powers and duties of the Civil Service Commission and Civil 
Service Department.

Serves as the Administrative Practice Officer for the President and the Civil Service Commission 
and acts as liaison with the Office of Administrative Procedure and its Director. 

Is responsible for the promulgation of rules in the New Jersey Register.

Formulates policies and procedures; plans, organizes and directs all departmental activities 
related to appeals of every nature coming before the Civil Service Commission, the President of 
the Civil Service Commission or the Chief Examiner and Secretary. This includes plenary hearing 
appeals arising from discipline by State or local appointing authorities, examination reviews, 
classification appeals, sick leave injury appeals, affirmative action appeals, grievances and 
general administrative appeals.

Formulates related policy and procedure and is responsible for the hearing program of the Civil 
Service Commission as well as liaison and coordinator on their behalf with the Office of 
Administrative Law and its Director. This includes responsibility for the administrative support 
functions of the Commission and the overall supervision of professional and clerical staff 
responsible for the preparation of Commission meetings and public hearings. 

Reviews hearing reports and decision drafts before submission to the Civil Service Commission 
and supervises completion of all assignments from the Civil Service Commission. 

Reviews formal decisions, orders and reports to assure their compliance with appropriate laws as 
they effect the administrative and regulatory functions of the Commission to assure that they 
conform to the established Commission policy and presidents.	

Prepares the Agenda for Commission meetings.

Represents the President in all activities with respect to labor relations, including: attendance at 
negotiations or the supervision of staff attending such negotiations; liaison with the office of the 
Governor on labor relation matters; preparation of policy statements and assistance in the 
formulation of policy by the President or the Commission; and preparation of advisory memoranda 
to the Department and outside the Departments or agencies with respect to labor relations 
activities where merit principles are involved. Represents the President as his designee to the 
Governor's Employee Relations Policy Council.

Assists the President in the formulation of legislative policy; coordinates, supervises and revises 
legislation. 

Plans, organizes and directs all department activity with respect to the drafting of legislation, and 
implementing rules, subparts and policy statements which are issued to State or local agencies by 
the President of the Commission or the Civil Service Commission.

Assists the President or his designated liaison with the Legislature in all matters relating to 
legislation; informs the President when bills requiring appearance of the President or his 
designated liaison are up for public hearing. Coordinates all comments from Divisions on 
legislation and prepares or directs preparation of the official legislative consents from the 
Commission, or the President to the Legislature. 

Supervises staff in tracking all bills and committee meetings of relevance. 

Attends legislative committee hearings with or in place of the legislative liaison on behalf of the 
President.

Prepares advisory replies interpreting application of Civil Service rules and regulatory matters to 
guide the Commission, the President of the Civil Service Commission, the Chief Examiner and 
Secretary and departmental divisions in their administrative decisions. Gives verbal advice and 
holds meetings for that purpose.

Acts as liaison with the Office of the Attorney General and disposes of requests from that office to 
this Department and the Commission. 

Prepares requests for advice from the President or the Commission to the Attorney General and all 
other correspondence related thereto.

Coordinates litigation with the Deputy Attorneys General assigned to the Department.

Acts as liaison with the Office of the Governor's Counsel, providing information to that office with 
respect to the work of the Department and the Civil Service Commission.

Formulates policy and procedures governing all investigations conducted by the Commission or 
the President.

Prepares for the Office of the Governor on behalf of the President, speeches, policies and 
statements and correspondence with respect to the Civil Service Act, any legislation amending or 
replacing that Act and matters bearing on the merit personnel management system.
 
Represents the President and the Civil Service Commission at meetings and gives speeches on 
their behalf.

Prepares formal reports; establishes and supervises maintenance of essential records and files.

Prepares the budget for the Division of Administrative Practices and Labor Relations.

Directs the operation of the Word Processing System for the Department. 

REQUIREMENTS

EXPERIENCE

Five years of professional experience in work involving the review, interpretation or drafting of laws, 
rules and regulations. Three years of such experience shall have included full time responsibilities 
as a legal counsel and/or an executive employee in a management position of a public 
employment merit system agency.

LICENSE

Admitted and licensed to the practice of law as an Attorney-at-Law in the State of New Jersey for a 
minimum of five years.

Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of 
a vehicle rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGES AND ABILITIES

Thorough knowledge of the New Jersey Civil Service Act, rules and regulations and their 
interpretation and application, including cases used as precedents.

Thorough knowledge of administrative law theory.

Thorough knowledge of and skill in reviewing, analyzing and reporting upon the potential effect of 
legislation, actual or proposed, upon Department policies.

Thorough knowledge of the procedures and techniques used in the preparation of advisory 
opinions based upon the Civil Service Act, related statutes, or Civil Service Rules and Regulations 
as requested by Department staff and State and local appointing authorities.

Thorough knowledge of developments in public labor law which may have an effect upon 
Department policy or labor negotiations, as well as the law, rules, theories, principles and practices 
of public sector labor relations.

Ability to organize assigned work relating to Civil Service law, regulations, hearings and appeals, 
analyze the varied problems arising therein, and develop appropriate work methods.

Ability to provide accurate advice to the Chief Examiner and Secretary and the President, Civil 
Service Commission, regarding existing interpretation and of Civil Service	law and regulation and 
related law and their effect upon Department policy.

Ability to prepare position papers and advisory memoranda pertaining to Civil Service law or 
related statues and Civil Service Rules and Regulations as required, including advisory 
correspondence.       

Ability to direct the review of hearing transcripts and exceptions or briefs by parties or attorneys 
and prepare technical comments thereon.

Ability to assign and instruct technical and other staff and supervise the performance of their work.

Ability to meet with the Governor's Counsel on proposed or pending legislation, direct the 
monitoring of State and Federal legislation and provide information to legislators regarding bills 
proposed or of interest to the Department.

Ability to provide current information regarding developments in public labor law.
 
Ability to direct the receipt and  processing appeals to the Commission and to assist in 
determining which appeal can be handles by the Chief Examiner and Secretary.

Ability to schedule and provide technical and clerical support for Hearing Officers and clerical 
support for Hearing Officers and the Civil Service Commissioners.

Ability to maintain statistic and collate pertinent legal documents. 

Ability to assign and direct the work of the Hearing Officers and set that the necessary transcripts 
are prepared. 

Ability to prepare extensive correspondence in in the course of official 

Ability to prepare clear, legally sound, accurate and information reports of legal and related 
Department and Commission matters.

Ability to supervise the maintenance of essential records, reports and files.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English sufficiently to perform the 
duties of this position. American Sign Language or braille may also he considered as acceptable 
forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can perform the essential 
functions of the job after reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations. if the 
accommodation cannot he made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such 
persons may not be eligible.


This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote63697SCNL38N/AM38-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 5/11/81

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Admitted and licensed to the practice of law as an Attorney-at-Law in the State of New Jersey for a minimum of five years.

alternativeQualifications: professional experience in work involving the review, interpretation or drafting of laws
licensed to the practice of law as an Attorney-at-Law in the State of New Jersey for a minimum of five years

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree, specifically a law degree (Attorney-at-Law), is absolutely required for this job. The job description specifies that the candidate must be admitted and licensed to practice law in New Jersey for a minimum of five years. The role involves a deep understanding of legal procedures, drafting of laws, rules, regulations, and interpretation of statutory authority which necessitates a professional legal qualification and experience. The position also requires significant experience as legal counsel and management in a public employment merit system, underscoring the need for specialized legal education and experience.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Admitted and licensed to the practice of law as an Attorney-at-Law in the State of New Jersey for a minimum of five years.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description for the position of Director of Appellate Practice and Labor Relations requires candidates to have five years of professional experience in work involving the review, interpretation, or drafting of laws, rules, and regulations, with three years as legal counsel and/or an executive employee in a management position of a public employment merit system agency. Additionally, candidates must be admitted and licensed to practice law as an Attorney-at-Law in the State of New Jersey for a minimum of five years. These qualifications typically necessitate a college or university degree in law, creating a barrier for applicants without such a degree.

name: Division Director Department Of Community Affairs
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


DIVISION DIRECTOR DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY AFFAIRS

UNCLASSIFIED
N.J.S.A 52:27D-29

DEFINITION:

Under the direction of the Commissioner, or other executive level official 
in the Department of Community Affairs, provides executive guidance 
and direction in the establishment and implementation of state and federal 
statues, rules, regulations, policies and procedures regarding the overall 
work operations, programs, activities and staff of a major operating 
Division: does related work as required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only.  
A particular position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this 
job specification.  Conversely, all duties performed on the job may not be 
listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Directs the technical and administrative activities and programs for a 
major operating Division.

Directs the assessment of division and community needs and plans 
and develops new programs to meet these needs.

Directs the planning for the impact of legislation and other changes 
on the Division Master Plan and existing systems.

Maintains overall responsibility for the preparation of annual budgets 
for both federal and state funds and for the overall fiscal integrity of 
the Division and its funds disbursal procedures.

Analyzes existing state and federal legislation and recommends 
changes or new legislation impacting on Divisionï¿½s programs.

Maintains close liaison with other appropriate state and federal 
agencies in the planning and implementation of programs.

Acts as principal advisor to the Commissioner/Assistant Commissioner, 
and ensures they are appraised of current activities, problems and 
developments on all matters related to the enhancement and 
management of the Division's programs.

Develops and maintains a management information system to direct 
progress in achieving goals and objectives and to ensure orderly and 
efficient handling of both long-term and other matters directly involving 
the Division.

Manages the work operations and/or functional programs of the division 
and has responsibility for employee evaluation and for effectively 
recommending the hiring, firing, promoting, demoting, disciplinary, an/or 
training of employees.

Oversees and provides executive guidance to staff involved in the study, 
evaluation and serving of community needs.

Delivers presentations, speeches, and testimonies before professional, 
technical and lay groups to disseminate programmatic management
information; establishes and maintains a cooperative and effective 
working relationship with same.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or 
manual recording and information systems used by the agency, office 
or related units.

REQUIREMENTS: 

EDUCATION:

Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelorï¿½s degree.

EXPERIENCE:

Eight (8) years of experience as an administrator involving planning, 
budgets and administration of programs in a large public or private 
agency, five (5) years)of which shall be in a supervisory capacity.

NOTE: Applicants who do not possess the required education may 
substitute additional experience as indicate above on a year for year 
basis.

NOTE:  Master's degree in Business, or Public Administration may 
be substituted for one year of non-supervisory experience.

LICENSE:

Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in 
New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee 
mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual 
recording and information systems used by the agency, office or 
related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English 
sufficiently to perform the duties of this position. American Sign 
Language or braille may also be considered as acceptable forms 
of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as 
they can perform the essential functions of the job after reasonable 
accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the 
accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the 
employer undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

Master's degree in Business, or Public Administration may be substituted for one year of non-supervisory experience.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: The job description specifies that a Bachelor's degree from an accredited college is a requirement, but it also allows for a substitution of additional relevant experience on a year-for-year basis in lieu of the degree. This suggests that while a higher educational degree is considered important, it is not absolutely required if an applicant possesses extensive relevant experience. The description further notes that a Master's degree in Business or Public Administration may substitute for one year of non-supervisory experience, highlighting that higher education is valued, but it is not the sole pathway to eligibility for the job.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description states that graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelor's degree is required for the position. Though it does mention that applicants who do not possess the required education may substitute additional experience on a year-for-year basis, this condition serves as an obstacle for those without a college degree. The requirement to substitute experience for education adds an additional layer of qualification and could limit opportunities for applicants without a degree.

name: Technical Assistant Public Employment Relations Commission
Senior Stock Clerk
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


 
 SENIOR STOCK CLERK
 
 DEFINITION

 Under supervision of a Supervising Stock Clerk or other supervisor in
 a state department, institution, or agency, either assumes the
 responsibility for a designated section of a large supply unit or
 takes the lead over a small number of stock clerks engaged in
 receiving, unloading, unpacking, sorting, issuing, shipping,
 delivering, and recording equipment, materials, and supplies of varied
 types; does other related duties.

 NOTE: The examples of work for this title are for illustrative
 purposes only. A particular position using this title may not perform
 all duties listed in this job specification. Conversely, all duties
 performed on the job may not be listed.

 EXAMPLES OF WORK:

 Organizes assigned or other stock work and develops effective work
 methods.

 Assumes the responsibility for maintaining a designated section of the
 stock room or area.

 Takes the lead in giving instructions to Stock Clerks and other
 employees assigned to the unit.

 Helps with unloading and unpacking shipments from trucks and/or
 freight cars.

 Checks incoming shipments for conformity with orders and
 specifications and sees that stock is in good condition.

 Sees that the stock bins and racks are kept supplied according to
 size, color, or other description and that sufficient quantity of
 stock is on hand at all times.

 When requisitions are received, assembles stock for order, and
 prepares it for shipment.

 Sorts and delivers packages, mail, and other items.

 Delivers packages, mail, and other supplies and equipment by use 
 of a motor vehicle.

 Checks orders being packed for delivery for quality, proper packing,
 and sufficient postage.

 Sees that the stock areas are maintained in a clean, orderly safe, 
 and sanitary condition, including floors, shelves, bin, and racks.

 Takes periodic inventories.

 Prepares reports.

 Maintains a set of stock record cards.

 Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or 
 manual recording and information systems used by the agency,
 office, or related units.

 REQUIREMENTS:

           EXPERIENCE:

      One (1) year of experience in work involving receiving, storing,
 and recording parts, materials, and supplies of varied types in an
 organized storeroom.

           LICENSE:

           Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license
 valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than
 employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties 
 of the position.

 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Knowledge of storage procedures and methods.

 Knowledge of stock record keeping methods and procedures.

 Knowledge of transportation, shipping, and packing methods.

 Ability to understand and carry out oral and written directions.

 Ability to learn quickly from oral and written explanations and from
 demonstrations.

 Ability to provide guidance and instruction to employees of the unit.

 Ability to operate and drive a motor vehicle to make deliveries or
 pickups.

 Ability to take the lead in unpacking, unloading, storing, sorting,
 labeling, and recording incoming stock of varied types and to 
 check the quality and quantity of stock received against orders 
 and specifications.

 Ability to see that the bins, racks, and shelves are kept filled.

 Ability to read and understand a road map to find locations within 
 the state.

 Ability to receive requisitions and see that stock is assembled for
 filling order, that proper records are kept thereof, and that the
 requested stock is properly packed for delivery and/or shipment.

 Ability to assist in the taking of periodic inventories.

 Ability to do simple clerical work and to prepare simple reports.

 Ability to assist in maintaining a set of stock record cards.

 Ability to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording
 and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

 Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in English
 sufficiently to perform the duties of this position. American Sign
 Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of
 communication.

 Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as
 they can perform the essential functions of the job after reasonable
 accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the accommodation
 cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship,
 such persons may not be eligible.
