You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.





Job Specification



 
JUDICIARY OF THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY 
Administrative Professional Band Specification
Administrative Specialist Track
Financial Specialist Track
     
    BAND SUMMARY
Administrative Professionals perform payroll, benefits, classification, labor/employee relations, salary administration, recruitment, training, Equal Employment Opportunity, Affirmative Action, finance, accounting, purchasing, committee support, research, analysis, investigation, mediation, hearing and/or general support professional functions for the vicinages or central office. This band is separated into two tracks: administrative specialist and financial specialist.
LEVEL SUMMARY (BOTH TRACKS)
Level 1-Basic (Administrative Specialist 2 and Financial Specialist): Employees at this level perform entry-level professional administrative and/or financial functions.
Level 2-Journey (Administrative Specialist 3, Judiciary Coordinator 1, Financial Specialist 1 andLibrarian 1): Employees at this level perform more complex professional administrative and/or financial functions.
Level 3 - Mastery (Administrative Specialist 4, Judiciary Coordinator 2 and Financial Specialist 2): Employees at this level perform advanced professional administrative and/or financial functions. Assigned to act as mentor or lead worker, provide technical advice and expertise, and/or act as a subject matter expert. Employees at this level also may conduct formal hearings and/or mediation sessions.
NOTE: The above summary and following examples of work are for illustrative purposes only. Any one position may not necessarily include all of the tasks listed, nor do the examples cover all of the duties, which may be performed. Tasks are cumulative; higher levels include the tasks associated with the lower.
TASKS (BOTH TRACKS)
Level 1
Act as a liaison and/or establish working relationships with divisions, vicinages or other outside organizations
Act as staff to committees and/or conferences
Address community organizations, public forums, media or professional associations
Analyze requisitions, vouchers, bank statements or financial transactions
Answer questions posed by judges, the public, clients, customers, complainants, co-workers, subordinates or supervisors
Arrange training for staff or team members
Assemble materials
Attend and participate in meetings outside of work unit/team
Calculate salary data
Check written reports for completeness or and accuracy
Collect data
Collect and/or maintain case statistics or financial data to generate status reports
Compile records or other written materials
Compile statistical data on workload volume, backlog, unit expenditures, personnel actions, financial transactions, fixed assets, equipment or attendance
Complete subpoenas, writs, or other related legal documents
Coordinate and schedule meetings and other events based on availability
Coordinate report collection activities
Coordinate workflow between units or chambers
Design forms, newsletters, flyers, brochures, booklets, and other documents for publication
Determine status of complaints in accordance with established procedures or regulations
Develop manuals, guides, audio-visual aids or other materials
Develop block diagrams, flow charts, graphs or other illustrative presentations
Draft correspondence, reports or proposals
Enter items as credits or debits
Establish and/or maintain record keeping and/or tracking systems
Explain judiciary policies or procedures
Inform clients or customers of available agency support programs or services
Inform managers about employees’, clients’ or customers’ work progress or related matters
Interview clients or customers for needed information and document acquired information
Interview complainants and document acquired information
Interview job applicants
Monitor, screen, and prepare disbursements
Negotiate with vendors
Obtain books and periodicals
Operate audio or video equipment
Operate electronic or manual information systems
Participate in team development activities
Participate in team/work unit meetings
Plan agendas for meetings
Prepare and enter accounting entries
Proofread opinions, legal briefs or other written materials
Provide cross-training to co-workers; for example, demonstrate to other staff how you perform your work
Provide human resources support for unit or agency, such as classification, compensation, payroll, benefits, recruiting, selection or training/development
Provide information to judges, attorneys or community organizations
Provide quality customer service to court users and/or internal customers
Purchase commodities
Recommend changes to organizational structure
Recommend improvements in judiciary programs
Recommend improvements in operating procedures, programs, standards, work processes, or administrative practices
Recommend purchases of equipment, materials or supplies
Reconcile bank accounts
Refer individuals to appropriate federal, state, county or local agencies
Review clients' or customers' records 
Review court activities for compliance with procedures, laws, court rules, or administrative directives
Review vendor bids or product history for cost savings or award of contract
Schedule meetings, appointments, interviews and other activities necessary for accomplishing job assignments
Serve on committees or task forces
Suggest improvements in work unit operation
Tabulate accounting, financial, or statistical data
Upload, duplicate, reformat, or destroy standard media format files as instructed
Verify clients’ or customers’ information
Verify entered data against source documents
Write technical specifications for purchase of equipment, parts and supplies
Write user or operations documents or manuals
Level 2
Advise management or supervisors on personnel issues
Advise managers on deadlines, rules, regulations or related information
Analyze cases in accordance with existing laws, regulations or professional practices
Analyze programs or work units to determine effectiveness or efficiency
Analyze work processes or methods
Assist in negotiating labor contracts and bargaining unit agreements
Communicate policies, rules or regulations to staff or team members
Conduct classification analysis
Conduct financial audits for accuracy, compliance or legitimacy following standards to maintain security or confidentiality
Conduct investigations
Conduct quantitative or qualitative research of processes, programs or projects
Conduct training sessions or orientations programs
Coordinate and facilitate various programs and/or special projects
Coordinate production of video recordings
Coordinate with heads of internal or external units or community
Coordinate work activities of unit or team members
Develop operating budgets
Develop performance standards and content materials for use in program and performance evaluation
Establish workflow systems or procedures
Evaluate program, unit or team performance in accordance with established policies or procedures
Give advice or assist staff or team members with work in progress
Implement operating procedures or systems
Interpret accounting, financial or statistical data
Investigate complaints
Make recommendations and acquire books, periodicals, and other research materials
Maintain and reshelf books and publications
Monitor terms of services and/or conditions in compliance with court orders
Prepare proposal for solicitation of bids for purchases of commodities
Prepare technical, statistical, financial, review or evaluation reports
Provide structured training to co-workers
Provide technical direction and support on special video recording events such as high profile trials
Reconcile fixed assets to ensure compliance with established policies and procedures
Respond to attorney, litigant or citizen complaints
Select training materials and resource documentation for training programs
Update lists of current library holdings
Level 3
Act as hearing officer
Act as lead worker to team members or other group of non-subordinates in assigned tasks
Determine staff or team member training needs 
Develop administrative and/or internal control systems
Develop communications plans within or outside the organization or unit
Develop curriculums for training programs for large scale audiences
Develop policies or procedures to ensure efficient court or unit operations
Direct and/or coordinate work between units or teams
Establish accounting systems
Facilitate discussion among federal, state, vicinage, county or local officials
Formulate plans for utilization of available funds, personnel, equipment, materials, and supplies
Keep abreast of current trends, laws and rules
Mediate various legal matters
Mentor and coach staff or team members; provide direction and feedback
Plan implementation of projects or programs
Provide higher level technical advice and/or expertise to staff, peers or management
Resolve disputes, conflicts or problems regarding programs or services
COMPETENCIES (BOTH TRACKS)
NOTE: The following competencies are cumulative in nature. For example, lower level competencies are prerequisite to higher levels.
Level 1
 Contracting and Procurement - Knowledge of various types of contracts and techniques for procurement.
Customer Service - Committed to providing quality services. Commands a thorough understanding of the customer, who he or she is, why and what he or she wants and needs. Focuses work on meeting and exceeding the customer’s needs. Develops and maintains strong relationships with internal and external customers, vendors or suppliers. Builds customer confidence in the ability to serve their needs.
Economics, Finance and Accounting - Knowledge of economic, financial and accounting principles and practices and the analysis of reporting financial data.
Human Resources - Knowledge of various personnel practices and procedures.
Information Management - Identifies a need for and knows where or how to gather information. Organizes and maintains information or information management systems.
Integrity and Honesty - Contributes to maintaining the integrity of the organization. Displays high standards of ethical conduct and understands the organization’s standards, including confidentiality in court operations, when appropriate, and the impact of violating these standards on the organization, self and others. Trustworthy.
Interpersonal Skills - Shows understanding, respect, collegiality, courtesy, tact, empathy, cooperation, concern, and politeness to others. Develops and maintains effective relationships with others; including effectively dealing with individuals who are difficult, hostile, or distressed. Relates well with people from varied backgrounds and different situations. Sensitive to cultural diversity, race, gender, disabilities, and other individual differences. Participates fully in team activities.
Legal/Government - Knowledge of laws, legal codes, legal documents, government regulations, executive orders, agency rules, New Jersey Rules of Court, government organization and functions.
Mathematical Reasoning - Performs computations, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication and division correctly using whole numbers, fractions, decimals and percentages. Solves practical problems by applying a variety of mathematical and statistical techniques.
Negotiating - Works with others towards an agreement.
Oral Communication - Effectively communicates information, for example, ideas or facts, to individuals or groups effectively, taking into account the audience and nature of the information, for example, technical, sensitive, controversial. Makes clear and convincing oral presentations. Listens to others, attends to nonverbal cues, and responds appropriately.
Organizational Awareness - Knows the organization’s mission and functions, and how its social, political, and technological systems work, and operates effectively within them, including the programs, policies, procedures, rules, and regulations of the organization.
Personal Development - Identifies and follows through on assignments, guidance and feedback to continuously learn and improve the performance and capabilities of one’s self.
Reading Comprehension - Understands and interprets written material; including technical material, rules, regulations, instructions, reports, charts, graphs or tables. Applies what is learned from written material to specific situations.
Reasoning - Identifies rules, principles or relationships that explain facts, data or other information. Asks pertinent questions to acquire needed information. Analyzes information and makes logical inferences or draws accurate conclusions.
Self-Management - Sets well-defined and realistic personal goal. Displays a high level of initiative, effort, and commitment towards completing assignments in a timely manner. Works with minimal supervision. Motivated to achieve. Demonstrates responsible behavior.
Stress Tolerance - Deals calmly and effectively with high stress situations, for example, tight deadlines, hostile individuals, emergency situations, dangerous situations.
Teamwork - Encourages and facilitates cooperation, pride, trust, and group identity. Fosters commitment and team spirit. Works with others to achieve goals.
Technical Competence - Uses knowledge that is acquired through formal training and/or extensive on-the-job experience to perform one’s job. 
Time Management - Establishes and manages priorities effectively. 
Total Quality Management - Shows attention to detail, accuracy and thoroughness. Committed to quality and excellence. Finds the root cause of problems. Looks for and makes continuous improvements. Follows through on implementing improvements and commitments made to others.
Written Communication - Composes correspondence, reports and other written material that is clear, concise, well organized and understood by recipient. Recognizes and uses correct English grammar, punctuation, and spelling. Communicates information, for example, facts, ideas, or messages, in a succinct and organized manner. Produces written information which may include technical material that is appropriate for the intended audience.
Level 2
Auditing - Knowledge of generally accepted auditing standards and procedures for conducting financial, compliance, economy and efficiency, and program results audits.
Contracting and Procurement - Knowledge of various types of contracts, techniques for contracting and/or procurement and contract negotiation and administration.
Decisiveness - Makes sound and well informed decisions. Perceives the impact and implications of decisions. Commits to action.
Financial Management - Plans, administers and monitors expenditures to ensure cost effective support of programs and policies.
Goal Orientation - Budgets time. Adjusts priorities in ways that meet optimal conditions. Manages multiple projects, priorities and deadlines.
Human Resources - Knowledge of hiring, classification, benefits, labor relations, negotiations and federal, state and local employment regulations.
Laws/Rules/Policies/Procedures - Interprets, understands, applies and complies with laws, rules, policies and procedures. Demonstrates familiarity with organizations policies/procedures and relevant laws and rules in human resources and management administration. Demonstrates familiarity with laws and rules related to critical finance, accounting, purchasing, training, labor/employee relations, EEO/AA, benefits law, job analysis, salary administration, selection, bargaining unit contract application and payroll administration. 
Negotiating - Negotiates to find mutually acceptable solutions.
Planning and Evaluating - Organizes work, sets priorities and determines resource requirements. Determines short or long term goals and strategies to achieve them. Coordinates with other organizations or parts of the organization to accomplish goals. Monitors progress and evaluates outcomes.
Professional Development - Keeps up-to-date on best practices available in the profession and attempts to implement those appropriate to the organization’s needs.
Teaches Others - Helps others learn through formal or informal methods. Identifies training needs. Provides constructive feedback. Coaches others on how to perform tasks. 
Technical Application - Uses machines, tools or equipment effectively. Uses computers and computer applications to analyze and communicate information in the appropriate format.
Level 3
Conflict Management - Manages and resolves conflicts, confrontations, and disagreements in a positive manner which minimizes negative impact.
Conflict Resolution - Reconciles, negotiates and mediates conflicts and/or grievances to acceptable solutions.
Cost - Keeps cost of achieving goals to a minimum. Sensitive to cost related issues. Maintains work within budgetary guidelines.
Counseling – Mentors, guides and coaches staff or team members. Provides feedback targeted at individual development.
Creative Thinking - Develops new insights into situations and applies innovative solutions to effectuate improvements or resolve problems. Designs new strategies as necessary where established methods and procedures are inapplicable, ineffective, inefficient, or unavailable.
Decision Making - Makes sound, well-informed and objective decisions. Perceives the impact and implications of decisions. Commits to action, even in uncertain situations, to accomplish organizational goals. Recommends, devises, and/or implements change. Effectively deals with ambiguity.
Financial Management - Prepares, justifies and/or administers the budget for program areas. Assesses financial condition of an organization.
Flexibility - Open to change and new information. Adapts behavior or work methods in response to new information, changing conditions, or unexpected obstacles.
Interpretation and Analysis of Written Materials - Comprehends and evaluates information, balancing the pros and cons to determine a desired outcome. Makes recommendations based upon logic or acquired knowledge. 
Leadership - Influences, motivates and challenges others. Adapts leadership styles to a variety of situations.
Visualization - Mentally organizes and processes symbols, pictures, graphs, objects or other information, for example, visualizes a building from a blueprint or visualizes the flow of work activities from reading a work plan.
Persuasion - Develops and articulates well thought out arguments to inform and persuade the decision maker where appropriate.
MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS
ADMINISTRATIVE TRACK
(Administrative Specialist 2, Administrative Specialist 3, Administrative Specialist 4,
Judiciary Coordinator 1, Judiciary Coordinator 2, and Librarian 1)
Education
Levels 1, 2 and 3:

For Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree in behavioral or social science, as specified in the Domestic Violence Hearing Officer Program Standards.


For custody, visitation, Children in Court Mediator positions*: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a graduate degree or certification of advanced training in a behavioral or social science and completion of a recognized mediation training program consisting of 40 hours of instruction.


For all other positions: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree.

Experience
Level 2
Three years of professional experience in the area of specialty specific to the job function being performed (see areas listed below).
Level 3:

For Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Five years of professional experience including three years of experience in the areas of domestic violence or family crisis.


For custody, visitation, children in court Mediator positions*: Four years of professional experience in one or more of the following areas: mediation, counseling, family intake, crisis intervention, custody/visitation dispute investigations and/or child support. This professional experience shall have included supervised clinical experience in mediation.


For all other Administrative Track Level 3 positions: Five years of professional experience in the area of specialty specific to the job function being performed (see areas listed below).

Levels 1, 2 and 3 Areas of Specialty:

Program Evaluation: program development, program coordination, program analysis, program administration and/or administrative research


Administrative Operations: purchasing, facilities management, operations management, records retention, transcript services, jury management, statistical reporting, investigations and/or library administration


Human Resources: payroll processing, benefits administration, salary administration, classification, labor/employee relations, training, selection/recruitment and/or Equal Employment Opportunity/Affirmative Action

Substitution

For custody, visitation, Children in Court Mediator positions*: At the discretion of the Assignment Judge relevant experience may be substituted for either the graduate degree or clinical experience, or both.


For all other Administrative Track Level 1, 2 and 3 positions except Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Applicants who do not possess the required education may substitute additional paraprofessional and/or professional experience on a year-for-year basis with one year of such experience being equal to 30 semester hour credits. An associate’s degree from an accredited college or university and two years of additional paraprofessional and/or professional experience may be substituted for a bachelor’s degree.

Note

For custody, visitation, Children in Court Mediator positions*: In: In special circumstances and at the request of the Assignment Judge, the Administrative Office of the Courts may temporarily approve for a one year period an applicant who has not yet completed the specialized family mediation training, provided the applicant has at least three years of experience as a Mediator or a combination of mediation experience and service in Family Part, has co-mediated in a CDR program with an experienced family mediator, and certifies to the intention to complete the specialized training within one year following the temporary approval.

Levels 2 and 3 (except Mediator positions)
A master’s degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for one year of experience.
Levels 2 and 3 (except Domestic Violence Hearing Officer and Mediator positions)
A law degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for two years of experience.

For Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Admission to the NJ Bar and one year of experience in family law, which shall include work involving domestic violence, may be substituted for one year of the required experience.

NoteNote: A master’s degree or a law degree from an accredited college or university, may be used as a substitution, not both. 
FINANCIAL TRACK
(Financial Specialist, Financial Specialist 1 and Financial Specialist 2)
Education
Levels 1, 2 and 3
Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor’s degree including or supplemented by 21 credit hours in accounting, business administration, economics, public administration and/or finance. Twelve of these credit hours must be in accounting.
Experience
Level 2 (Financial Specialist 1)
Three years of professional accounting, finance, auditing and/or budgeting experience.
Level 3 (Financial Specialist 2)
FiveFive years of professional accounting, finance, auditing and/or budgeting experience.
Substitution
All Levels
Applicants who do not possess the required education, but do possess the 21 accounting, business administration, economics, public administration, and/or finance credit hours, including 12 accounting credit hours, may substitute additional paraprofessional and/or professional experience on a year-for-year basis with one year of such experience being equal to 30 semester hour credits. 
Levels 2 and 3
A master’s degree from an accredited college or university in business or public administration, economics, accounting or finance may be substituted for one year of general experience -OR- a CPA designation may be substituted for one year of general experience as indicated above.
License
Appointees will be required to possess a driver’s license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelorâs degree.
A masterâs degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for one year of experience.
A law degree from an accredited college or university may be substituted for two years of experience.

master's degree in specific fields

mandatoryStatusExplanations.bothTrueExplanation:
The job description for the positions in the Judiciary of the State of New Jersey indicates that a degree is mandatory, as it specifies education requirements for each level. For example, a bachelor's degree is required for entry, with substitutions allowed for experience in certain cases. Additionally, master's or law degrees can substitute some years of experience for higher levels, reinforcing that having a degree or the equivalent qualifications is necessary for these roles.

The job description also indicates that there are alternative qualifications in place of the specified degrees, as it allows for the substitution of experience for the degree requirement. For instance, additional paraprofessional and professional experience can substitute for educational credits, and an associate's degree along with equivalent work experience is acceptable in lieu of a bachelor's degree. This provision demonstrates that while a degree is mandatory, there are alternative pathways through experience that fulfill the educational requirements.
mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: Based on the job description provided, a higher educational degree is not absolutely required for the job. While a bachelor's degree is generally preferred for levels 1, 2, and 3 in both the administrative and financial tracks, there are substitution options available. For example, additional relevant experience can be substituted for the educational requirements on a year-for-year basis for most positions. Furthermore, specific qualifications such as paraprofessional or professional experience, a master's degree, or a CPA designation can be substituted for experience in some cases. Therefore, the educational requirements can be met through a combination of education and relevant work experience, indicating that a higher educational degree is not strictly necessary.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: For Domestic Violence Hearing Officer positions: Admission to the NJ Bar

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description contains barriers to hiring an applicant who does not have a college or university degree. Specifically, for all positions (except where explicitly stated otherwise), there is a requirement for graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree. There are some substitution provisions, where a combination of paraprofessional and professional experience can substitute for the degree requirement, or an associate's degree combined with additional experience may also be substituted for a bachelor's degree. However, these substitutions still place a significant emphasis on the attainment of formal educational qualifications, which acts as a barrier for those without a degree. Additionally, for Financial Track positions, specific credit hours in accounting and related fields are required, further reinforcing the educational barriers.

name: Public Health Consultant 2
text:
Job Specification 62864G 











	
		
	    
	
	
		
			
				
					
				   
				
		  
	  
	
	
		 
	
	
		You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
	
	
		
	
	
		
	  
	
	
		
  
    
Job Specification 62864G 

PUBLIC HEALTH CONSULTANT 2, SOCIAL WORK

 

DEFINITION


 Under direction of a supervisory official, defines, promotes, and
 otherwise  provides consultative services to public  and  private
 medical  social services programs; does other related  duties  as
 required.

 NOTE: The definition and examples of work for this title are for
 illustrative  purposes only.  A particular  position  using  this
 title   may   not  perform  all  duties  listed   in   this   job
 specification.  Conversely, all duties performed on the  job  may
 not be listed.

 
EXAMPLES OF WORK:


 May  assist  in  assessing, planning, promoting,  and  developing
 medical social services throughout the state.

 Interprets  medical  social  services  and  maintains   effective
 working relationships with professional, educational, public, and
 voluntary  agencies  and  other groups concerned  with  providing
 medical social services to achieve coordination on same.

 Plans  and  helps develop community medical social services,  and
 provides expert technical consultation and guidance.

 Works   with   community   agencies  to  achieve   and   maintain
 professional clinical social work standards.

 Participates   in  institutes,  group  meetings,  seminars,   and
 inservice and educational training programs, and participates  in
 surveys, studies, and selected demonstration projects.

 May  assist  in recruitment, selection, and training  of  medical
 social work personnel within the department and other agencies.

 Gives talks as may be required.

 Prepares  detailed  correspondence  in  the  course  of  official
 duties.

 Prepares  and  supervises the preparation of  clear,  technically
 sound,  accurate,  and  informative statistical,  financial,  and
 other  related  reports  containing  findings,  conclusions,  and
 recommendations.

 Maintains the establishment and maintenance of essential  records
 and files.

 Will  be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic
 and/or  manual  recording and information  systems  used  by  the
 agency, office, or related units.

 REQUIREMENTS:

      EDUCATION:

      Graduation from an accredited college or university  with  a
 Master's degree in Social Work.

      EXPERIENCE:

      Three   (3)  years  of  experience  providing  consultation,
 advice,  and technical assistance to community organizations  and
 other  professionals on social work problems, prevention efforts,
 problem solving techniques, treatment methods and plans, and case
 management procedures.

      LICENSE:

      Appointees  will  be required to possess a driver's  license
 valid  in  New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle,  rather
 than   employee  mobility, is necessary to perform the  essential
 duties of the  position.

 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Knowledge  of  current methods and techniques of  medical  social
 work used in public health and other health and welfare agencies.

 Knowledge  of techniques and practical approach used in locating,
 training,   and   working  with  leaders   of   cooperating   and
 participating agencies to promote medical social work..

 Knowledge  of  principles and practices of public  administration
 methods in relation to social work.

 Ability  to apply standards, policies, rules, and regulations  of
 the  State  Department of Health and Senior Services to  specific
 situations.

 Ability  to  plan, coordinate, promote, and evaluate the  medical
 social   work   component  of  health  services,  and   to   make
 recommendations to alleviate problem areas based on research  and
 current developments in social work.

 Ability  to identify problem areas in social work administration,
 and  develop  recommendations to solve these  problems  based  on
 current standards and assessments of the needs of the health care
 facility or organization.

 Ability to research solutions to questions concerning social work
 from  health  care  facilities, or local  or  county  health  and
 welfare organizations.

 Ability  to  plan,  organize, and evaluate  medical  social  work
 programs.

 Ability  to  conduct and/or assist in research and  demonstration
 projects.

 Ability  to prepare informational material for annual and monthly
 reports.

 Ability  to plan, organize, and carry out programs of orientation
 and inservice training for staff.

 Ability to coordinate medical social services with other programs
 of  the  department and with other public, private, and voluntary
 health and/or welfare agencies.

 Ability  to  prepare  correspondence in the  course  of  official
 duties.

 Ability  to  compile  data for and to prepare sound,  technically
 accurate, and comprehensive periodic, statistical, progress,  and
 other    reports    containing   findings,    conclusions,    and
 recommendations.

 Ability  to  utilize various types of electronic  and/or   manual
 recording and information systems used by the agency, office,  or
 related units.

 Ability  to  read, write, speak, understand, and  communicate  in
 English  sufficiently  to perform the duties  of  this  position.
 American   Sign  Language or Braille may also  be  considered  as
 acceptable forms of  communication.

 Persons  with  mental or physical disabilities  are  eligible  as
 long as they can perform the essential functions of the job after
 reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations.   If
 the   accommodation  cannot be made because it  would  cause  the
 employer undue  hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

 CODES: 24/P24-62864G              CAH                  6/18/97

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Master's degree in Social Work.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: Yes, a higher educational degree is absolutely required for this job. The job specification explicitly states that a Master's degree in Social Work from an accredited college or university is a requisite requirement. This educational requirement is essential due to the complexity and specialized nature of the duties and responsibilities listed, which include providing expert consultation, planning medical social services, and developing recommendations based on in-depth knowledge and research in social work.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Master's degree in Social Work is a requirement for this position, creating a barrier for applicants who do not have a college or university degree.

name: Claims Adjudicator Support Specialist 2
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification



 CLAIMS ADJUDICATOR SUPPORT SPECIALIST 2
 

 DEFINITION

 Under the direction of a supervisory official, Division of
 Disability Determination Services, performs claims support and
 clerical work in the compilation of medical and non-medical data
 in the adjudication of claims filed under the Social Security
 Disability Programs; does other related duties.

 NOTE: The examples of work for this title are for illustrative
 purposes only.  A particular position using this title may not
 perform all duties listed in this job specification.  Conversely,
 all duties performed on the job may not be listed.

 NOTE: Appointments may be made to positions requiring 
 bilingual skills.

 64942C - Bilingual in Spanish and English
 SPECIAL SKILL
 Applicants must be able to read, write, speak, understand, or 
 communicate in Spanish and English sufficiently to perform 
 the duties of this position.


 EXAMPLES OF WORK:

 Prepares medical evidence records through written correspondence.

 Extracts data from files and codes relevant information on the
 appropriate forms.

 Telephones claimants to obtain missing or additional information
 to complete development of claims.

 Receives and opens mail regarding claims filed through the AS400
 system or other information system.

 Sorts medial and other evidence with appropriate case file.

 Contacts non-medical sources ascertain additional evidence needed
 to make a final determination.

 Receives and responds to inquiries on status of claims.

 Contacts claimants for permission to obtain additional medical
 evidence.

 Keeps tickler files up to date.

 Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic
 and/or manual recording and information systems used by the
 agency, office, or related units.


 REQUIREMENTS:

      EDUCATION:

 Successful completion of sixty (60) semester credit hours at
 an accredited college.

      EXPERIENCE:

 One (1) year of experience in the collection and
 verification of information and data for eligibility
 determination for benefits or services.

      NOTE: Applicants who do not possess the required education
 may substitute additional experience as indicated above on a year-
 for-year basis thirty (30) semester credit hours is equal to one
 (1) year of experience.

      LICENSE:

 Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license
 valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather
 than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential
 duties of the position.


 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Ability to read and interpret the disability provisions of the
 Social Security Program.

 Ability to comprehend and apply the standards and procedures for
 collecting and recording of medical and other data.

 Ability to follow directions and to complete specific forms used
 in the division.

 Ability to learn basic terms in human anatomy, physiology,
 pathology, psychiatry, and childhood diseases.

 Ability to maintain essential records and files containing
 reports on medical and other evidence.

 Ability to correspond verbally and in writing with claimants,
 advocates, medical and non-medical sources to obtain the
 necessary information to make determination.

 Ability to prepare simple reports of completed actions.

 Ability to understand relevant codes to extract medical and non-
 medical data from files.

 Ability to communicate effectively and courteously with
 claimants, both orally and in writing.

 Ability to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual
 recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or
 related units.

 Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in
 English sufficiently to perform duties of this position.
 American Sign Language or Braille may also be considered as
 acceptable forms of communication.

 Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long
 as they can perform essential functions of the job after
 reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations.  If
 the accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the
 employer undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

This job specification is applicable to the following title code(s) whichare different work week or work month and/or variants of the job class title:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote64942SC3513N/AA12-64942CBilingual In Spanish And EnglishSC3513N/AA12-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 9/11/1999

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Successful completion of sixty (60) semester credit hours at an accredited college.

alternativeQualifications: One (1) year of experience in the collection and verification of information and data for eligibility determination for benefits or services

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: The job description for the Claims Adjudicator Support Specialist 2 in the State of New Jersey requires either successful completion of 60 semester credit hours at an accredited college or one year of relevant work experience related to eligibility determination for benefits or services. Therefore, a higher educational degree is not absolutely required for this job as the educational requirement can be substituted with equivalent work experience.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description requires the successful completion of sixty (60) semester credit hours at an accredited college. However, it specifies that applicants who do not possess the required education may substitute additional experience on a year-for-year basis, with thirty (30) semester credit hours equating to one (1) year of experience. This requirement could be a barrier for applicants lacking a college or university degree but offers a pathway through equivalent work experience.

name: Planning Associate 3 School/Education Programs
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


PLANNING ASSOCIATE 3, SCHOOL/EDUCATION PROGRAMS

DEFINITION

Under direction, in the Department of Education, supervises the analysis, 
establishment, and administration of operating  and grants-in-aid budgets 
for state, federal, and other funding  sources; analyzes management practices 
and financial controls in order  to assess their adequacy to implement 
education plans and increase  program efficiency and cost savings; 
supervises the development of  education programming by conducting 
analyses and evaluation of  educational programs, surveys, needs 
assessments, and program fiscal  data related to state and federal formula 
aid and discretionary grant  applications and allocations; and/or supervises 
the design and management of research studies related to school funding 
areas; and/or supervises the monitoring of all financial areas for school 
districts; performs mandated regulatory functions; works with a high level 
of independence; supervises staff and work activities; prepares and signs 
official performance evaluations for subordinate staff; does related work as 
required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only.  
A particular position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this 
job specification.  Conversely, all duties performed on the job may not be 
listed.
  
EXAMPLES OF WORK

Plan, organize, and assign the work of the organizational unit and evaluate 
employee performance and conduct, enabling the effective recommendation 
of the hiring, firing, promoting, and disciplining of subordinates.

Supervise the design and implementation of evaluation instruments to analyze 
effectiveness of education services in local school districts and intermediate 
and regional units.

Supervises the analysis of the management systems and financial controls 
in order to assess their adequacy to implement education plans and to 
increase program efficiency and cost effectiveness.

Supervise the monitoring, review, analysis, and approval of lease purchase 
and bond fund transactions for school districts.

Supervise the review or review applications for extension of credit and 
recommend approval or disapproval.

Supervise the review or review to ensure that lease purchase and bonding 
transactions of school districts meet generally accepted accounting standards.

Supervise the review or recommend bond forms and requirements from 
various entities for lease/purchase of school facilities.

Supervise the review or review and recommend approval or disapproval 
of terms of lease/purchase agreements and extension of credit applications.

Supervise the conductor conduct hearings on school lease/purchase 
agreements and refinancing or defeasance applications.

Develop and maintain operating budget and financial controls for the 
school districts, programs and/or the department.

Develop cost estimates for proposed programs for the school districts, 
programs and/or the department.

Supervise the monitoring or monitor the acquisition and disbursal of 
education grants.

Determine impact on educational programming from changes in funding, 
personnel, programs, or services.

Supervise the establishing and the maintenance of effective work 
communications with county offices and regional units to ensure 
education programs are being met.

Supervise the auditing of program records and finances.

Establish and administer operating and grants-in-aid budgets and 
expenditures for state, federal, and other non-state funding sources.

Supervise the review and/or conduct financial and compliance review 
of accounts, financial transactions, and program outcomes.

Supervise the analysis of or analyze relevant state and federal laws and 
regulations and develop policy and program recommendations for their 
enforcement.

Establish and maintain liaison with education and public interest groups, 
to inform them of departmental activities and identify needs.

Supervise and/or research and analyze census, demographic, labor 
market, and technological data and establish education programs and 
plans to meet changing needs.

Ensure that technical assistance is provided to local programs and 
coordinate the development of education programs for funded 
agencies as needed.

Supervise the development of specialized programs for targeted 
populations.

Design and manage research studies of various school funding sources 
and related economic areas, such as cost analysis, school finance theory, 
fiscal resource measurement, school reform, and funding formulas.

Review, establish and determine priorities for education programs, 
services, and funding.

Supervise the ongoing maintenance of local district education goals 
and progress toward meeting these goals and recommend improvement
 in meeting goals.

Monitor the ongoing statewide implementation and evaluation of 
instructional programs and ensure adherence to federal law and 
regulations.

Supervise the preparation of budgets and negotiation of terms and 
conditions of third party grants and contracts with local education 
agencies and other providers.

Supervise the development of funding criteria and competitive grant 
application procedures for awarding contracts to eligible agencies.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or 
manual recording and computerized information systems used by 
the agency, office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS

EDUCATION

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Master's 
degree in Public Administration, Educational Administration, Business 
Administration, Accounting, or a related field.

NOTE:  Possession of a valid Certificate as a Certified Public Accountant 
issued by the New Jersey State Board of Certified Public Accountants 
may be substituted for the Master's degree.

EXPERIENCE

Five (5) years of professional experience in school business 
management/accounting or public or private sector budgeting, 
accounting, or auditing.

LICENSE

Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in 
New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee 
mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of the organization and structure of the New Jersey Education 
system.

Knowledge of public education policy at the local, state, and federal levels.

Knowledge of state and federal laws, regulations, policies and procedures 
governing public sector budgeting, purchasing, accounting and/or auditing.

Knowledge of principles and practices for improving specialized education 
programming at the local level.  

Knowledge of State and Federal statutes and administrative codes as 
they apply to education.

Knowledge of state and federal program aid requirements.

Knowledge of legislation and guidelines related to funded programs.

Knowledge of the operational processes and practices of state agencies, 
including the fiscal system.

Knowledge of budgeting methods and principles.

Knowledge of cost-benefit analysis.

Knowledge of law and regulation regarding lease purchase agreements 
for school districts.

Knowledge of bonding and financing of capital projects.

Knowledge of principles and techniques of program monitoring and auditing.

Knowledge of Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and Procedures 
(GAAP).

Knowledge of principles and practices of employee supervision.

Knowledge of principles and practices for providing education programming 
at the local level.

Knowledge of state school aid financing.

Knowledge of school funding formulas.

Ability to supervise assigned staff and plan, organize, and implement 
projects within the unit.

Ability to manage complex budgets and financial records.

Ability to apply guidelines and procedures to grant and aid allocation.

Ability to establish and maintain working and informational networks 
with education and public interest groups.

Ability to exercise leadership in program planning development with 
department staff, county offices, regional units and local school district 
staff.

Ability to coordinate plans and resources, and identify areas of potential 
problems or additional needs.

Ability to analyze data and prepare accurate reports of findings, conclusions, 
and recommendations.

Ability to prepare accurate documentation of budgetary needs.

Ability to interpret federal rules and regulations and develop a responsive 
plan for meeting special needs.

Ability to prepare extensive official correspondence.

Ability to coordinate program maintenance, fiscal reporting, other 
essential files.

Ability to develop school funding formulas.

Ability to conduct analytic research studies.

Ability to develop technical assistance materials.

Ability to plan and conduct regional and statewide in-service training 
programs.

Ability to synthesize needs assessment information into responsive 
program plans.

Ability to analyze state and federal labor projections and identify 
appropriate educational programs to meet these needs.

Ability to analyze trends and project future educational needs based 
on these trends.

Ability to maintain essential records, reports and files.

Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual 
recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or 
related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English 
sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.  American Sign 
Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms 
of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long 
as they can perform essential functions of the job with or without 
reasonable accommodation. If the accommodation cannot be 
made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, 
such persons may not be eligible.


This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote72632SNNL30N/AR30-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 4/01/2017

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Master's degree in Public Administration, Educational Administration, Business Administration, Accounting, or a related field.

alternativeQualifications: Possession of a valid Certificate as a Certified Public Accountant issued by the New Jersey State Board of Certified Public Accountants

mandatoryStatusExplanations.bothTrueExplanation: The job description for the Planning Associate 3, School/Education Programs specifies a requirement for a Master's degree in a relevant field like Public Administration, Educational Administration, Business Administration, or Accounting. Furthermore, it offers an alternative qualification by allowing possession of a valid Certificate as a Certified Public Accountant issued by the New Jersey State Board of Certified Public Accountants as a substitute for the Master's degree. Thus, both DegreeRequirementStatus.isDegreeMandatory and DegreeRequirementStatus.hasAlternativeQualifications are True, as the degree is mandatory unless the candidate possesses the specified professional certification, which is accepted as an equivalent qualification.
mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: For the job of Planning Associate 3, School/Education Programs, a higher educational degree is required as the position demands a Master's degree in fields like Public Administration, Educational Administration, Business Administration, Accounting, or a related field. The educational requirement indicates the need for advanced knowledge and specialized skills that typically accompany a graduate-level education, such as an in-depth understanding of educational systems, budgeting, financial management, and program evaluation, which are critical for executing the job functions effectively. Additionally, a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) certification can substitute for the Master's degree, reflecting the necessity for a high level of expertise and competence in accounting and financial management.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Master's degree in Public Administration, Educational Administration, Business Administration, Accounting, or a related field is required. Possession of a valid Certificate as a Certified Public Accountant may be substituted for the Master's degree. This constitutes a barrier for individuals who do not have a college or university degree or certification as a Certified Public Accountant.

name: Business Representative 1

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Possession of a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university; and three (3) years of the above-mentioned professional experience.

Possession of a Master's degree from an accredited college or university in Political Science, Education, Economics, Psychology, Sociology, Public Administration, Business Administration, Marketing, Communications, Personnel/ Human Resources Management, or related fields; and two (2) years of the above-mentioned professional experience.

alternativeQualifications: Seven years of professional experience in the implementation, coordination, or marketing of an employment and training or business services program in a public or private agency

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for this job. While the possession of a bachelor's or master's degree can reduce the required years of professional experience needed, the job can also be obtained solely through seven years of relevant professional experience in the field. This implies that the skills and competencies necessary for this role can be acquired through extensive work experience, without necessarily holding a college degree.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants:
The job description for the Business Representative 1 position suggests potential barriers to hiring an applicant without a college or university degree. Specifically, the position requires either:

1. Seven (7) years of relevant professional experience.
2. A bachelor's degree and three (3) years of relevant professional experience.
3. A Master's degree in specific fields and two (2) years of relevant professional experience.

While it is possible to qualify with professional experience alone, the requirements place significant emphasis on the combination of educational qualifications and experience, which could act as a barrier for candidates without a college or university degree.

name: Occupational Therapist
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification



 OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST
                          ALL JURISDICTIONS
 

 DEFINITION

 Under  the direction of a Senior Occupational Therapist  or  other
 supervisor,  assists  in  the  professional  occupational  therapy
 program;  may be assigned the responsibility for a specific  phase
 of the professional therapy program; does other related duties.

 NOTE: The  examples of work for this title are for  illustrative
 purposes  only.  A particular position using this  title  may  not
 perform  all duties listed in this job specification.  Conversely,
 all duties performed on the job may not be listed.

 EXAMPLES OF WORK:

 As  directed,  assists with the work involved in the programs  and
 activities of the occupational therapy program of the institution.

 Assists  in  the  planning and execution of  occupational  therapy
 activities for specified patients and groups of patients.

 Consults with other rehabilitation team members to select activity
 programs   consistent  with  patients'  needs  and   capabilities;
 coordinates    occupational   therapy   with   other   therapeutic
 activities.

 May  assign,  instruct, and supervise the work of  Therapy  Aides,
 Therapy  Assistants, and other institution employees  assigned  to
 the occupational therapy unit.

 Reviews  patients' records and the recommendations of the  medical
 staff;   prepares  and  conducts  specific  occupational   therapy
 programs for individual patients.

 As   required,   may  attend  and  participate  in   medical   and
 occupational therapy staff and other meetings and conferences.

 Assists  with  sales  and  exhibits of articles  produced  by  the
 occupational therapy unit.

 Prepares  and maintains records of individual patients  and  other
 records,  including  equipment  inventories,  attendance  records,
 articles completed, and patient progress, and statistical reports.

 Will  be  required to learn to utilize various types of electronic
 and/or  manual  recording  and information  systems  used  by  the
 agency, office or related units.

 May  be  required to engage in lifting clients when working  in  a
 setting  which provides direct services to clients  who  are  non-
 ambulant,  or  who are semi-ambulant and/or have  severe  physical
 handicaps.

 REQUIREMENTS:

      EXPERIENCE:

           One (1) year of experience in Occupational Therapy.

           LICENSE:

      Applicants   must  possess  a  license  as  an   Occupational
 Therapist  issued  by the Occupational Therapy  Advisory  Council,
 Department of Law and Public Safety.

           Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license
 valid  in  New  Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle,  rather
 than  employee  mobility, is necessary to  perform  the  essential
 duties of the position.

            NOTE: Appointees to positions in day training centers
 and  other  educational facilities identified by  the  New  Jersey
 Department   of  Education  will  be  required  to   possess   the
 appropriate  educational certification issued by  the  New  Jersey
 Department of Education.

       SPECIAL  NOTE: Ability to physically lift, move and position
 clients as needed.

 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Knowledge  of the principles, standards, practices, and techniques
 of occupational therapy.

 Knowledge  of  occupational therapy materials  and  equipment  and
 their utilization.

 Knowledge  of  the  problems encountered in  occupational  therapy
 work.

 Ability to physically lift, move, and position clients as needed.

 Ability  to  organize  assigned  occupational  therapy  work,  and
 develop appropriate work methods.

 Ability to plan, conduct, and supervise the course of occupational
 therapy for designated patients.

 Ability  to assign, instruct, and supervise Therapy Aides, Therapy
 Program   Assistants,  and  other  employees   assigned   to   the
 occupational therapy unit.

 Ability to read and interpret rules and regulations and apply them
 to specific situations.

 Ability  to  work  harmoniously with  medical  staff,  supervisory
 officers,  and patients and others involved with the  occupational
 therapy program.

 Ability  to  prepare  accurate and detailed patient  progress  and
 other  reports  of  the  occupational therapy  program  containing
 findings, conclusions, and recommendations.

 Ability to maintain records and files.

 Ability  to  learn  to utilize various types of electronic  and/or
 manual  recording  and information systems  used  by  the  agency,
 office, or related units.

 Ability  to  read,  write, speak, understand,  or  communicate  in
 English  sufficiently  to  perform the duties  of  this  position.
 American  Sign  Language  or Braille may  also  be  considered  as
 acceptable forms of communication.

 Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as  long
 as  they  can  perform the essential functions of  the  job  after
 reasonable  accommodation is made to their known limitations.   If
 the  accommodation  cannot  be made because  it  would  cause  the
 employer undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote03671SN4019N/AP20-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 9/23/2000

mandatoryStatusExplanations.bothFalseExplanation: Both DegreeRequirementStatus.isDegreeMandatory and DegreeRequirementStatus.hasAlternativeQualifications are False because the job description specifies the requirement of a professional license (Occupational Therapist license) issued by the Occupational Therapy Advisory Council without mentioning the need for a specific degree. This indicates that obtaining the necessary license is sufficient to qualify for the position. Consequently, there are no alternative qualifications listed, as possessing the relevant license is the key requirement.
mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is absolutely required for this job as the applicant must possess a license as an Occupational Therapist issued by the Occupational Therapy Advisory Council, Department of Law and Public Safety. In order to obtain this license, an individual must have completed an accredited occupational therapy program, which typically requires at least a bachelor's degree in occupational therapy, though often a masterâs degree is expected. Furthermore, the job's responsibilities and skills require significant specialized knowledge and training that would typically be acquired through such an educational program.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Applicants must possess a license as an Occupational Therapist issued by the Occupational Therapy Advisory Council, Department of Law and Public Safety.
professionalLicenseRequirement.issuingAuthority: Occupational Therapy Advisory Council, Department of Law and Public Safety

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description for the Occupational Therapist position in New Jersey does not explicitly state or suggest any barriers or obstacles to hiring an applicant who does not have a college or university degree. However, it does require applicants to possess a license as an Occupational Therapist issued by the Occupational Therapy Advisory Council, Department of Law and Public Safety, which generally necessitates a degree in occupational therapy as part of the licensing process. This indirectly suggests a barrier for those without a degree.

name: Business Manager 1
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


 BUSINESS MANAGER 1

 DEFINITION:

 Under direction of the chief executive officer in a large institution
 in a State-operated institution, oversees and manages the business
 activities of the institution, including the preparation of the
 operating and capital budget on a program basis; the purchase,
 storage, and distribution of equipment, materials, and supplies; food
 service program; the farm and powerhouse operations; property control;
 the maintenance of buildings and grounds; the condition of furnishings
 and equipment throughout the institution; and the preparation of
 financial and other related reports and records; does other related
 work.

 NOTE: The examples of work for this title are for illustrative
 purposes only. A particular position using this title may not perform
 all duties listed in this job specification. Conversely, all duties
 performed on the job may not be listed.

 EXAMPLES OF WORK:

 Develops policies, programs, procedures, and plans for the management
 of business activities at the institution.

 Prepares the operating and capital budgets on a program basis for the
 institution.

 Administers rules, regulations, and standards for the accounting and
 fiscal activities of the institution.

 Handles insurance coverage for buildings and institutional contents.

 Serves as liaison officer in the settlement of all fire insurance
 claims and adjustments.

 Prepares and executes plans for the effective utilization of available
 funds, personnel, equipment, materials, and supplies.

 Provides assignments and instructions to unit heads and other
 employees and supervises the performance of their work.

 Supervises the general business operation of the institution,
 including the preparation and maintenance of financial personnel, 
 and other reports and records.

 Supervises the purchase, receipt, storage, and distribution of
 equipment, materials, and supplies.

 Supervises the compilation, analysis, interpretation of data relating
 to collection, expenditures, budgets, stores, and other matters.

 Supervises the allocation of budgeted funds to institutional programs
 and the maintenance of appropriate records.

 Maintains liaison and cooperative working relationships with business
 office staff and the other units of the institution.

 Supervises institution fire and police protection measures where
 applicable.

 Plans farm programs in cooperation with the Farm Supervisor where
 required.

 Supervises the preparation of time records and payrolls.

 Conducts inspections of institutional grounds and facilities,
 including farm, power plant, storeroom, kitchen, food service and
 other areas to review work operations and programs, and to ensure 
 that buildings and facilities are properly maintained.

 Prepares correspondence.

 Prepares and supervises the preparation of clear, sound, accurate, 
 and informative statistical, financial, budget, and other reports on
 institution business management and related matters.

 Supervises the establishment and maintenance of institution records
 and files.

 Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or 
 manual recording and computerized information systems used by
 the agency, office, or related units.

 REQUIREMENTS:

 EDUCATION:

 Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelor's degree in 
 business, public or hospital administration, accounting, finance, 
 economics or commerce.

 EXPERIENCE:

 Seven (7) years of financial experience in a medical, educational, 
 correctional or training facility, or other business operation which 
 shall have included the preparation of financial statements and 
 reports, review of financial records, overseeing the development 
 of internal accounting control procedures, and assisting in the 
 development and analysis of an office, unit, agency or organizational 
 budget, four (4) years of which shall have been in a supervisory 
 capacity.

 NOTE: A Master's degree in business administration,
 accounting, commerce, public administration, finance, economics or
 hospital administration may be substituted for one (1) year of the
 indicated non-supervisory experience.

 KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

 Knowledge of the varied factors involved in the business management 
 of an institution.

 Knowledge of budget methods and techniques.

 Knowledge of business administration practices.

 Ability to read and interpret laws and regulations impacting the
 operations and programs of an institutional environment and apply 
 them to specific situations.

 Ability to develop work programs and schedules for the business 
 unit and sub-divisions.

 Ability to plan for the effective utilization of available funds,
 personnel, equipment, materials, and supplies in an institutional
 environment.

 Ability to provide assignments and instructions to staff and supervise
 the performance of their work.

 Ability to collect data for and prepare budget requests, and supervise
 allocation of budgeted funds.

 Ability to supervise institution business transactions.

 Ability to inspect institutional grounds and facilities to review work
 programs and operations.

 Ability to prepare correspondence.

 Ability to prepare and supervise the preparation of clear, sound,
 accurate, and informative statistical, financial, budget, and related
 institution reports containing findings, and recommendations.

 Ability to supervise the maintenance of financial and related
 institution records and files.

 Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual
 recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or
 related units.

 Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English
 sufficiently to perform the duties of this position. American Sign
 Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of
 communication.

 Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as
 they can perform the essential functions of the job after reasonable
 accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the accommodation
 cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship,
 such persons may not be eligible.

 CODES: 33/M33 - 50666           MCK            6/3/00

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelor's degree in business, public or hospital administration, accounting, finance, economics or commerce.

A Master's degree in business administration, accounting, commerce, public administration, finance, economics or hospital administration may be substituted for one (1) year of the indicated non-supervisory experience.

alternativeQualifications: Seven years of financial experience in specified facilities with at least four years in a supervisory capacity

mandatoryStatusExplanations.bothTrueExplanation:
The job description clearly states that a Bachelor's degree in business, public or hospital administration, accounting, finance, economics or commerce is required for the position of Business Manager 1. Therefore, the degree is mandatory for this role.

Additionally, while there is a provision for substituting one year of non-supervisory experience with a Master's degree, there are no alternative qualifications mentioned that can replace the requirement for a Bachelor's degree, indicating that no alternative qualifications are accepted in lieu of it.
mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: In assessing whether a higher educational degree is absolutely required for the Business Manager 1 position described, we must consider the outlined job requirements within the job description. The position specifies that a Bachelor's degree in business, public or hospital administration, accounting, finance, economics, or commerce is necessary. Additionally, while it is not mandatory for this degree to be at the Master's level, a Master's degree can substitute for one year of non-supervisory experience, suggesting that a higher degree is beneficial though not required. The role demands significant financial and supervisory experience (seven years, with four years in a supervisory capacity). This indicates that while a Bachelor's degree is required as a minimum educational threshold, the combination of specialized experience and advanced education could enhance a candidate's capability to fulfill the duties but is not strictly required.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description specifies that applicants are required to have graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelor's degree in business, public or hospital administration, accounting, finance, economics, or commerce. This requirement presents a barrier for applicants who do not have a college or university degree, as it is explicitly stated as a qualification for the position.

name: Supervisor Office Of Management And Budget
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SUPERVISOR , OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET

DEFINITION

Under the general direction of a higher level manager in the Department 
of Treasury, manages  a fiscal, budgetary, or administrative program or unit 
which has a single objective and determines goals and objectives of the unit; 
plans and develops the policies and procedures necessary to accomplish 
these goals, and manages the work processes of the program and staff; 
does related work as required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only. 
A particular position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this 
job specification. Conversely, all duties performed on the job may not be 
listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK:  

Reviews agencyï¿½s program plans, budgets, appropriations, operating reports, 
and other available information to identify programs or program components 
in which substantive problems or issues exist which require investigation 
and/or analysis; assists in defining the issue or developing plans for conduct 
of the analysis.

Reviews reports and statistical information containing findings, conclusions, 
and recommendations

Manages the development, implementation, and integration of new programs.

Writes notices, memoranda, or news releases about policy changes, major 
events, or other information.

Manages the establishment and maintenance of extensive accounting and 
related records and files.

Directs the preparation of reports and statistical information containing 
findings, conclusions, and recommendations.

Coordinates the education, training, and development plan for assigned 
personnel.

Develops procedural and training manuals for the program.

Examines documents for adherence to applicable laws and regulations.

Interprets applicable laws, policies, rules, and regulations for subordinates.

Provides advice and consultation concerning policy issues associated with 
program compliance and organizational goals and objectives 

Consults with outside agencies or individuals about information necessary
for job assignments.

Provides advice and consultation concerning planning issues directly 
concerning policy, and organizational goals and objectives.

Manages the work operations and/or functional programs and has 
responsibility for effectively recommending the hiring, firing, promoting, 
demoting and/or disciplining of employees.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual  
recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or related 
units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EDUCATION:

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor's 
degree in Management Science, Economics, Accounting, Public or 
Business Administration, Political Science, Finance, Mathematics, 
Public Policy, Government Administration, Actuarial Science, Statistics, 
or Budgeting.

NOTE:  A Masterï¿½s degree in one of the above areas from an accredited 
college or university will satisfy the education requirement irrespective of 
the area of concentration at the Bachelor's level.

EXPERIENCE:

Six (6) years of experience in a fiscal, budget, or administrative unit in a 
public or private agency having responsibility for the determination of  
program goals and objectives, the planning and development of policies
and procedures, and the organization of the work processes of the program 
and staff, three (3) years of which shall have been in  a supervisory capacity.

NOTE:  A Master's degree in any of the above areas may be substituted for 
one (1) year of the nonsupervisory work experience.

NOTE:  Possession of a doctorate degree in an area of study listed above 
may be substituted for two (2) years of the nonsupervisory work experience.

LICENSE:

Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey 
only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary 
to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of principles, methods, and techniques of supervision and 
management.

Knowledge of management science concepts and practices including 
Management by Objectives, Program Planning and Budgeting Systems, 
Operations Research, and Systems Analysis

Knowledge of principles, methods, and procedures used to evaluate 
program activities

Knowledge of budgeting and planning practices and procedures, program 
analysis, organization principles, and administrative practices.

Knowledge of organizational lines of communication (formal and informal).

Knowledge of administrative principles and practices.

Knowledge of procedures for reconciling accounts.

Knowledge of program evaluation techniques.

Knowledge of the principles and techniques of resource allocation.

Knowledge of federal programs including regulations and the impact of 
these programs and regulations on the funding of state programs.

Knowledge of administrative planning and scheduling techniques such 
as network analysis, PERT, or Gantt charts.

Knowledge of the principles and techniques of program monitoring.

Knowledge of Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and Procedures
