(GAAP) and Generally Accepted Auditing Standards and Procedures (GAAS).

Ability to analyze, interpret, and apply laws and regulations to specific 
situations.

Ability to prepare and present clear, comprehensive, and accurate reports 
on office programs and related issues containing findings, conclusions, and 
recommendations based on data assembled.

Ability to prepare extensive correspondence in the course of official duties.

Ability to prepare budgets and supervise expenditures.

Ability to supervise assigned staff and plan, organize, and implement 
projects within the unit.

Ability to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording 
and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English 
sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.  American Sign 
Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of 
communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as 
they can perform the essential functions of the job after reasonable 
accommodation is made to their known limitations.  If the accommodation 
cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, 
such persons may not be eligible.


This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote99938SCNL34N/AM34-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 8/31/2019

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor's degree in Management Science, Economics, Accounting, Public or Business Administration, Political Science, Finance, Mathematics, Public Policy, Government Administration, Actuarial Science, Statistics, or Budgeting.
A Masterâs degree in one of the above areas from an accredited college or university will satisfy the education requirement irrespective of the area of concentration at the Bachelor's level.
Possession of a doctorate degree in an area of study listed above may be substituted for two (2) years of the nonsupervisory work experience.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree, specifically a Bachelor's degree in a relevant field, is required for the job as stated in the job description. This requirement ensures that the candidate possesses the necessary knowledge in areas such as management science, economics, accounting, and public or business administration, which are essential for managing fiscal, budgetary, or administrative programs. Additionally, a Master's degree is considered advantageous as it can substitute for part of the experience requirement, indicating the importance of advanced education in fulfilling the responsibilities of the role.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.
professionalLicenseRequirement.issuingAuthority: Department of Motor Vehicles - New Jersey

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description states that a Bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university in specific fields is required, which serves as a barrier to applicants who do not have a college or university degree. Additionally, there is a note that a Master's or Doctorate degree can substitute for part of the required experience, further emphasizing the need for higher education credentials.

name: Chief Of Investigations

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Possession of a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university; and six (6) years of the above-mentioned professional experience, three (3) years of which shall have included supervisory responsibility.

Possession of a master's degree in public administration, business administration, social work, or criminal justice; and five (5) years of the above-mentioned professional experience; three (3) years which shall have included supervisory responsibility.

alternativeQualifications: Ten (10) years of professional office and/or professional field experience
Experience as a police officer performing criminal follow-up investigations

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for the Chief of Investigations job, as the requirements allow for a combination of experience and education. Applicants can qualify with ten years of professional experience in investigations, including three years of supervisory experience, without a college degree. Alternatively, possessing a bachelor's or master's degree can substitute for some years of experience, but is not mandatory. Therefore, extensive relevant experience can compensate for a lack of a higher educational degree.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants:
The job description presents barriers to hiring an applicant without a college or university degree, as it specifies certain educational qualifications as alternatives to experience:

1. Possession of a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university along with six (6) years of required professional experience, with three (3) of those years including supervisory responsibility.
2. Possession of a master's degree in public administration, business administration, social work, or criminal justice, with five (5) years of required professional experience, three (3) of which must have included supervisory responsibility.

These educational requirements serve as a barrier for applicants who do not possess a college or university degree. However, the job description does allow for the substitution of experience, suggesting a combined approach of experience and education could also qualify an applicant.

name: Crew Supervisor Electricians
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


CREW SUPERVISOR, ELECTRICIANS

DEFINITION:

Under direction of a supervisor in a state department, institution, or agency, 
supervises a group of electricians and other employees engaged in the 
installation, repair and maintenance of electrical equipment; prepares or 
works with sketches, plans and specifications; works with tools and testing 
equipment common to the trade.  Supervises staff and work activities.  
Prepares and signs official performance evaluations for subordinate staff; 
does related work as required.
  
EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Develops and maintains work plans and procedures for the installation, 
repair and maintenance of elevators, motors, wiring, cables, public address 
systems, feeder systems, refrigerators, radios and other types of electrical 
equipment, appliances, machinery and circuits.

Assigns work, gives written and/or oral instruction to the Electricians and 
their helpers and supervises the performance of their work.

Inspects and supervises the inspection of electrical wiring, fixtures, 
appliances, motors, generators, pumps, power circuits and controllers 
of machines and elevators; sees that repair and installation work is done.

Supervises the work operations and/or functional programs and has 
responsibility for effectively recommending the hiring, firing, promoting, 
demoting and/or disciplining of employees.

Supervises and takes the lead in the installation of electrical wiring, 
cables, fixtures and appliances.

Sees that emergency electrical repair work is done.

When required, instructs the inmates of state institutions in simple 
electrical work.

Orders, stores, safeguards and supervises the use and recording of 
electrical equipment, materials, and supplies.

Prepares reports and records of equipment, personnel, time costs and 
work completed.

In the Department of Human Services, may be required to undergo fire 
training classes.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual 
recording and computerized information systems used by the agency, 
office or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EXPERIENCE:

Four (4) years of experience in work involving the installation, inspection, 
repair and maintenance of electrical equipment, appliances, machinery 
and circuits.

NOTE:  Applicants who do not possess the required experience may 
substitute a current Electrical Contractor license issued by the New Jersey 
Department of Consumer Affairs for three (3) years of experience.

LICENSE:

Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey 
only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary 
to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of the problems, equipment and techniques involved in installing, 
inspecting, repairing and maintaining cables, wiring, motors, generators, 
pumps, refrigerators, radios, sound equipment, oil burners and other types 
of electrical equipment, appliances, fixtures, machinery and circuits.

Knowledge of the problems involved in making electrical work plans and 
schedules.

Ability to supervise assigned staff and plan, organize and implement 
projects within the unit.

Ability to give written and/or oral directions to employees assigned to 
electrical work and supervise the performance of their work.

Ability to analyze problems involving electrical installation, inspection, 
maintenance and repair work and develop effective work methods.

Ability to install, inspect, repair, and maintain cables, wiring, motors, 
generators, pumps, refrigerators, radios, sound equipment, oil burners 
and other types of electrical equipment, appliances, fixtures, machinery 
and circuits and to supervise employees engaged in such work.

Ability to prepare estimates of electrical work and to keep records of 
work done, materials used, personnel and time spent.

Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording 
and information systems used by the agency, office or related units.
 
Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English 
sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.  American Sign Language 
or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they 
can perform essential functions of the job with or without reasonable 
accommodation.  If the accommodation cannot be made because it would 
cause the employer undue hardship, such persons may not be eligible.

  CODE:  41345       2/7/2015

alternativeQualifications: Four (4) years of experience in work involving the installation, inspection, repair and maintenance of electrical equipment, appliances, machinery and circuits
A current Electrical Contractor license issued by the New Jersey Department of Consumer Affairs for three (3) years of experience

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: For the position of Crew Supervisor, Electricians as described, a higher educational degree is not absolutely required. The primary requirement is four years of relevant work experience in electrical installation, inspection, repair, and maintenance. Additionally, possessing a current Electrical Contractor license can substitute for three years of the required experience. Thus, practical experience and technical knowledge in the field are emphasized over formal educational degrees for this supervisory role.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description does not explicitly mention a requirement for a college or university degree, nor does it suggest that such a degree is necessary. The primary qualification is four years of relevant experience in electrical work, with an option to substitute most of this experience with a current Electrical Contractor license issued by the New Jersey Department of Consumer Affairs. Therefore, there are no explicit barriers to hiring an applicant without a college or university degree.

name: Supervising Agricultural Products Agent
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SUPERVISING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS AGENT

DEFINITION

Under the direction of a supervisory officer in the New Jersey
Department of Agriculture, supervises the work force assigned to
regulatory service programs including inspection, certification, 
grading, standardization and enforcement involving numerous fresh
and processed agricultural commodities; supervises the sampling of 
materials and products used in plant and livestock production; 
inspections of wholesale and retail dealers to ensure proper 
licensing; and the labeling of agricultural commodities at point of 
sale; performs special investigations; directs investigators and 
complex program oversite as well as development of the 
program  to enforce the  New Jersey Milk Control Act, Chapter 274, 
P.L.  1941, as amended; enforces and translates the  provisions of 
the law and assists milk dealers, processors, and retail merchants in 
milk marketing problems; monitors and controls the inventory in 
the warehouses for minimal loss nd maintenance of quality and 
wholesomeness; supervises the work of Agricultural Products 
Agents who monitor the receipt, allocation, utilization, storage and 
distribution of federally donated food commodities to eligible 
recipient agencies; provides administrative support for the 
electronic information processing system to ensure continued and 
uninterrupted monthly allocations of U.S.D.A. commodities to all 
eligible recipient agencies within New Jersey; supervises staff and 
work activities; prepares and signs official performance evaluations 
for subordinate staff; does other related duties.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative 
purposes only. A particular position using this title may not perform 
all duties listed in this job specification. Conversely, all duties 
performed on the job may not be listed.
 
EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Assigns and delegates workloads to inspection and grading 
personnel.

Supervises the issuance of official certificates and reports, including 
various official United States Department of Agriculture Marketing 
and Distribution Certificates, in compliance with State/Federal and 
Foreign requirements, including shipping point, receiving market, 
phytosanitary, export and import inspections.

Participates in industry meetings and provides technical advice and 
assistance on agricultural commodity grading problems and 
programs.

Supervises the work operations and/or functional programs and has 
responsibility for effectively recommending the hiring, firing, 
promoting, demoting and/or disciplining of employees.

Supervises the collection of samples of animal feeds, seeds, 
fertilizers, soil conditioners and liming materials for Departmental 
laboratory analysis.

Participates in the development of contracts for inspection and 
grading services, works with agricultural commodity processors 
and packers to develop proper terminology in processors/packer-
grower contracts.

Supervises and assigns the inspection and grading personnel and 
ensures that work performance is in accordance with applicable 
laws, regulations and State/Federal standards and grades.

As required supervises the verification of prices and proper dating 
of agricultural commodity packages and containers, and proper 
labeling of commodities and materials such as lime, feed, fertilizers, 
potatoes and eggs.

Supervises the interpretation and application of official standards
and grades for agricultural products by bureau personnel.

Participates in the training and supervision of inspection and 
grading personnel, dairy investigation personnel and Food 
Distribution personnel.

Conducts laboratory evaluations of milk processing plants and holds
the appropriate license to act as a Laboratory Evaluation Officer (LEO).

Certifies laboratory technicians to perform sanitary and safety tests 
on raw milk used for processing milk and milk products.

Supervises and acts as test proctor for the Weigher/Sampler 
licensees.

Conduct and supervise detailed warehouse audits of products for 
dealers, and to analyze such information to determine regulatory
compliance.

Conduct and/or supervise the collection and analysis of detailed 
financial information as it relates to variable cost pricing and to 
explain variable cost as defined in the regulations for stores,
dealers, and for any other legal matters.

Assists in planning and organizing of Division investigations in highly 
sensitive and complicated cases.

Obtains affidavits from complainants, licensees, or witnesses to 
support or refute allegations relevant to cases conducted by the 
Division.

Assists with the compilation and organization of pre-investigative 
research.

Reviews licensing records for background information in 
formulating the course of action of an investigation.

Supervises and arranges conferences related to investigative cases.

Review labels of consumer packaging for approval and/or 
compliance with the New Jersey labeling regulations and those of 
the Pasteurized Milk Ordinance (PMO) and/or Certified Organic 
Program.

Review for compliance and approval of ï¿½cents off promotionsï¿½ as 
they related to the New Jersey Milk Control Act.

Investigates Dealers and Processors to collect evidence for a 
hearing/mediation on a violation. 

Acts as Department representative to submit evidence at hearings. 

Conducts field hearings and mediation for dairy violations. 

Settles Disputes and violations.

Participates in the development of ï¿½Value Added Dairy Marketingï¿½.

Plans and organizes investigations of dealers, processors, and stores 
to collect evidence for a hearing/mediation on a violation.

Provides advice on packaging, inspection, grading and regulatory 
matters to Department and industry personnel, serves as an expert 
witness on such matters as required.

Cooperates with Federal and State organizations and agencies.

Provides advice to farmers on grading and standardization 
requirements.

Supervises the inspection of facilities proposed for Controlled 
Atmosphere (CA) storage of agricultural commodities; supervises 
the inspection of approved facilities for temperature and 
percentages of oxygen and carbon dioxide compliance.

Supervises the maintenance and issuance of equipment and
provides instructions for use.

Reviews and analyzes activity and other operational reports.

Prepares reports of the Commodity Inspection and Grading 
programs or in the Food Distribution programs containing findings, 
conclusions and recommendations.

Prepares correspondence.

Develops work programs for Agricultural Products Agents verifying 
the compliance of recipient agencies with regulations concerning 
the receipt, transportation, distribution, storage and utilization of
federally donated food commodities.

Meets with prospective sponsors of needy-feeding programs.

Guides recipient agencies in the development of efficient 
management practices related to food commodities, use 
inventories, withdrawal and use records, temperature 
requirements, dry storage, refrigerated storage and freezer 
storage practices.

Meets with federal representatives regarding the inspection of 
record keeping, utilization, receipt, storage, distribution, claims 
and processing agreement practices of recipient agencies.

Meets with representatives of recipient agencies to identify their 
needs, arrange for delivery schedules, and determine utilization 
requirements for federal foods.

Provides guidance and instruction to field employees and supervises 
the performance of their work.

Provides administrative support for the daily operation of the 
electronic data system for the monthly allocation offering of food.

Supervises the sampling and collection of Federal foods for 
analytical testing to ensure food quality meets State and Federal 
regulations and standards.

Processes claim losses due to shortages, damages, spoilage and 
prolonged storage.

Supervises the establishment and maintenance of essential records 
and files.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or
manual recording and information systems used by the agency, 
office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

Five (5) years  of  experience  in fresh fruit and vegetable grading 
and inspection; or in food safety systems auditing; or in field and
internal related work as an agricultural commodities regulation 
enforcement officer; or as a food service director.

NOTE:  Possession of a United States Department of Agriculture 
unrestricted Interstate/Intrastate Market license may be substituted 
for one (1) year of experience.

NOTE: Possession of a United States Department of Agriculture 
Processed Base Auditors license may be substituted for one (1) year 
of experience.

NOTE:  Possession of a Food and Drug Administration, Grade A 
Milk Sanitation License may be substituted for one (1) year of 
experience.

LICENSE:

NOTE:  Appointees may be required to qualify for federal and/or 
State licenses or certifications for agricultural commodities 
inspections and/or food safety inspections.

NOTE:  Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license 
valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than 
employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of
the position.

SPECIAL NOTE:  The duties of this title may require heavy lifting.
Appointees will be expected to perform duties where heavy lifting 
of objects such as crates of ice, packed poultry, and dry pack cases
of eggs, fruits, vegetables, seafood, red meat, frozen/refrigerated,
canned commodities, and other objects will be required.

NOTE:  Appointees may be expected to detect color variations and 
undesirable odors in commodities being inspected and/or graded.

KNOWLEDGES AND ABILITIES

Knowledge of the methods used to inspect food products.

Knowledge of agriculture products, standards and grades, and other
quality specifications for agricultural commodities.

Knowledge of laboratory evaluations of milk processing plants.

Knowledge of certification procedures to certify laboratory 
technicians to perform sanitary and safety tests on raw milk used 
for processing milk and milk products.

Knowledge of the problems encountered in soliciting voluntary 
observance of grading procedures for the marketing of fruits and
vegetables.

Knowledge of the trade practices for handling, packing, storage 
and distribution of food.

Knowledge of the types, volume and production schedules of
various agricultural commodities.

Knowledge of the methods used to develop and supervise food
distribution programs.

Ability to supervise assigned staff and plan, organize, and 
implement projects within the unit.

Ability to supervise and act as test proctor for the Weigher/Sampler 
licensees.

Ability to conduct and supervise detailed warehouse audits of
products for dealers, and to analyze such information to determine
regulatory compliance.

Ability to conduct and/or supervise the collection and analysis of 
detailed financial information as it relates to variable cost pricing
and to explain variable cost as defined in the regulations for stores,
dealers, and for any other legal matters.

Ability to investigate Dealers and Processors to collect evidence for
a hearing/mediation on a violation. 

Ability to act as Department representative to submit evidence at 
hearings. 

Ability to conduct field hearings and mediation for dairy violations. 

Ability to settle Disputes and violations without consultation with 
Coordinator of Dairy Program.

Ability to provide assignments and instructions to staff and 
supervise their performance.

Ability to provide advice on packing, inspection and grading of food.

Ability to supervise the collection of food and other samples for 
analysis and testing.

Ability to interpret laws, rules and regulations and apply them to 
specific regulations.

Ability to establish and maintain cooperative working relationships
with associates, subordinates, and others involved in the work of 
the program.

Ability to prepare correspondence.

Ability to prepare reports containing findings, conclusions, and 
recommendations.

Ability to supervise the establishment and maintenance of essential 
records and files.

Ability to meet with representatives of food recipient agencies to 
identify and expedite their needs.

Ability to supervise the issuance and use of equipment and supplies.

Ability to develop plans for the utilization of electronic data 
systems.

Ability to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording 
and information systems used by the agency, office, or related 
units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in 
English sufficiently to perform duties of this position. American Sign 
Language or Braille may also be considered as acceptable forms of
communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as  
long as they can perform essential functions of the job with 
or without reasonable accommodation.  If the accommodation 
cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue  
hardship, such persons may not be eligible.


This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote33894SCN421N/AS22-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 9/03/2016

alternativeQualifications: Five (5) years of experience in fresh fruit and vegetable grading and inspection
Food safety systems auditing
Field and internal related work as an agricultural commodities regulation enforcement officer
Experience as a food service director

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: Based on the job description for the position of Supervising Agricultural Products Agent, a higher educational degree is not explicitly required. Instead, the requirements focus on five years of experience in relevant fields such as fruit and vegetable grading and inspection, food safety systems auditing, agricultural commodities regulation enforcement, or as a food service director. Additionally, possession of specific licenses (e.g., USDA unrestricted Interstate/Intrastate Market license, USDA Processed Base Auditors license, FDA Grade A Milk Sanitation License) can substitute for a portion of the required experience. The emphasis is on knowledge, licensure, and demonstrated abilities related to agricultural products, as well as supervisory experience.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees may be required to qualify for federal and/or State licenses or certifications for agricultural commodities inspections and/or food safety inspections.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants:
- The job description does not explicitly state that a college or university degree is required.
- The requirement section specifies "Five (5) years of experience in fresh fruit and vegetable grading and inspection; or in food safety systems auditing; or in field and internal related work as an agricultural commodities regulation enforcement officer; or as a food service director" as necessary qualifications. There is no mention of needing a degree, which suggests that experience is more critical than formal education.
- The ability to learn and utilize various types of electronic and manual recording and information systems is required, but this doesn't specify needing a degree.
- Although there is an emphasis on specific knowledge and abilities, such as knowledge of the methods used to inspect food products and experience with agricultural commodities, these can be gained through experience rather than formal education.
- Despite these points, there are no stated, suggested, or described barriers to hiring an applicant who does not have a college or university degree.

name: Special Agent 2

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Possession of a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university; and two (2) years of the above-mentioned professional experience.
Possession of a Master's degree in Public Administration, Business Administration, or Criminal Justice; and one (1) year of the above-mentioned professional experience.

alternativeQualifications: Six (6) years of professional experience conducting investigations, collecting evidence, and/or preparing investigative reports related to criminal and/or civil matters

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for this job. The job requirements state that applicants can either have six years of relevant professional experience or possess a bachelor's degree with two years of experience or a master's degree with one year of experience. Therefore, extensive relevant experience can substitute for a higher educational degree, making the degree not strictly necessary for this position.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees must possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants:
The job description presents the following barriers for applicants who do not have a college or university degree:

1. The requirement of "Posession of a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university; and two (2) years of the above-mentioned professional experience." This could be a barrier for those without a degree.

2. Alternatively, the job allows for "Six (6) years of professional experience conducting investigations, collecting evidence, and/or preparing investigative reports related to criminal and/or civil matters." This provides a pathway for individuals without a degree, but they must have significant relevant experience.

Overall, while the degree is not an absolute requirement if substantial professional experience can be demonstrated, the preference for candidates with a bachelor's or master's degree might put those without any college education at a potential disadvantage.

name: Director Office Of Highway Traffic Safety
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


DIRECTOR OFFICE OF HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY

Unclassified: NJSA 27:5F-29

DEFINITION

Assists the Chief of Traffic Safety of the Division of Motor Vehicles in the collection, compilation 
and analysis of traffic accident reports concerning accident frequencies, their causes and 
contributing factors in terms of the driver the vehicle and the roadway, in the interest of improving 
the safety and expedition of traffic.

Assists in supervising the review of and makes recommendations concerning all traffic ordinances, 
resolutions, and regulations and orders as required by the traffic control statute (Title 39).

Assists in supervising traffic-engineering operations having to do with regulatory devices such as 
signs, signals, markings, speed surveys, etc., in the interest of traffic safety and expedition.

Assists in the conduct of a statewide safety education program for all age groups. This activity 
includes school program in pedestrian and bicycle safety; high school driver education programs, 
and teacher training and adult safety programs.

Assists the thief of the Traffic Safety Service in his capacity as supervisor of the County Traffic 
Safety Coordinator Program for the Attorney General.

Is primarily responsible for carrying out traffic safety activities of all types, including public 
information, public support and special training programs.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only.  A particular 
position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this job specification.  Conversely, all 
duties performed on the job may not be listed.

EXAMPLES OF WORK: 

Under the direction of the Attorney General, is instrumental in arranging and conducting New 
Jersey's Annual Governor's Traffic Safety Conference.

Assists in conducting polls, surveys and studies for the improvement of traffic conditions.

Assists in the supervision of the State's Alcohol Determination Program in all fatal traffic accidents.

Assists in the supervision of special experimental programs, such as several recent pilot studies in 
pedestrian safety.

Supervises the preparation of safety posters, pamphlets, teaching aids and related materials.

Assists County and Municipal Officials in the application of engineering, enforcement and 
educational principles.

Assists in the supervision of all administrative and clerical duties associated with the activities 
mentioned above.

Will be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and 
information systems used by the agency, office or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EDUCATION: 

Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree.

EXPERIENCE: 

Five (5) years of administrative experience in a large government agency, which shall have 
involved the responsibility for law interpretation and enforcement

LICENSE: 

Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation 
of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES: 

Knowledge of and familiarity with the laws of New Jersey relating to motor vehicles and traffic and 
of the regulations of the Division of Motor Vehicles promulgated thereunder.

Knowledge of the rules, regulations, internal organization, standards, procedures and programs of 
the Division of Motor Vehicles.

Ability to organize assigned technical work and to develop effective work methods.

Ability to comprehend, analyze and interpret basic law and regulations.

Ability to heir clan, organize and carry to completion special projects and research studies in 
specific motor vehicle regulation and traffic problems and to prepare detailed reports thereon for 
the Chief of the Traffic Safety Service.

Ability to utilize modern statistical theory, methods and devices in reporting the work of the Division.

Ability to act as a consultant and advisor to the Director of Motor Vehicles in terms of accumulating 
experiences of the Division. Ability to prepare extensive correspondence.

Ability to prepare dear, sound, accurate and informative statistical, financial and other Division 
reports containing findings, analyses, conclusions and recommendations

Ability to direct the establishment and maintenance of essential records and filer.

Ability to stand instead of the Chief of the Traffic Safety Service in all respects in the Chief's 
absence.

Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording information systems 
used by the agency, office or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English sufficiently to perform the 
duties of this position. American Sign Language or braille may also be considered as acceptable 
forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can perform the essential 
functions of the job after reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the 
accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such 
persons may not be eligible.

This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote30357SUNL98N/AM98-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 00/00/00

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: The job description for the Director of the Office of Highway Traffic Safety requires graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree. This educational requirement indicates the necessity for a higher educational degree to ensure the candidate has a foundational level of knowledge and skills pertinent to the responsibilities of the role. The tasks described involve analysis, comprehension of laws and regulations, organization of work, and preparation of extensive correspondence and reports, all of which are typically supported by the education provided through a bachelor's degree. Additionally, the nature of guiding traffic safety programs, interpreting law, and conducting research studies also necessitates a level of critical thinking and analytical skills typically acquired through higher education.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description states a requirement for "Graduation from an accredited college or university with a bachelor's degree," which presents a barrier for applicants who do not have a college or university degree.

name: Special Investigator State Lottery
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SPECIAL INVESTIGATOR, STATE LOTTERY 52344
Unclassified 
(N.J.S.A. 11:4-4u)

DEFINITION 

Under direction of the Deputy Director, Security, Audit and Licensing, Division of State Lottery, 
Department of the Treasury, assists in the coordination of and performs complex and specialized 
investigations of considerable regulations and State laws governing the operation of the State 
Lottery; performs related work as required.

EXAMPLES OF WORK

Investigates possible violations of rules and regulations of the Lottery Commission and of laws of 
the State of New Jersey pertaining to Lottery operations.

Organizes assigned cases and develops effective work methods. Prepares reports to the Grand 
Jury as required by the Prosecutor.

Obtains, secures and preserves evidence for presentation to the Grand Jury as required by the 
Prosecutor.

Testifies in court, in the event of criminal prosecutions pertaining to Lottery instituted cases.

Coordinates investigations pertaining to Lottery Operations with the State Attorney General, 
Federal Bureau of Investigation, County and Municipal authorities.

Investigates complaints against Lottery agents and compiles detailed reports for the use of the 
Director at hearings.

Investigates disputes between Agents and Claimants and arranges amicable settlements where 
possible.

Confers with Courier Service and their security personnel on matters related to Lottery 
investigations.

Conducts background investigations of individuals applying for licenses as Lottery agents.

Inspects courier facilities and operations to determine whether vendors comply with contractual 
requirements.

Conducts confidential investigations relating to the Lottery Commission and Lottery employees.

Prepares reports of assets of Lottery debtors for possible seizure by the State Attorney General.

Conducts security checks and evaluations of suppliers of Lottery tickets. Conducts security 
inspections of Lottery office facilities.

Conducts continuous review of Lottery security procedures and makes necessary changes to meet 
changing conditions.

Conducts confidential and/or undercover investigations as directed by Deputy Director pertaining 
to the integrity of the on-line and Instant ticket lottery games.

Reviews confidential computer log tapes pertaining to maintaining the integrity of the Lottery and 
Lottery agents on disputed winners claims.

Conducts investigations pertaining to integrity of sensitive computer files and printouts.

Prepares clear, technically accurate and comprehensive reports of investigations and submits 
findings and recommendation on varied correspondence.

Maintains essential records and files.

REQUIREMENTS 

Education 

Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelor's degree.

Experience 

One year of experience as a member of a civil or military law enforcement or investigative agency 
performing field investigations.

Applicants who do not possess the required education may substitute the indicated experience on 
a year for year basis.

License 

Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of 
a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

Knowledges and  Abilities

Wide knowledge of the accepted methods of conducting field investigations with emphasis on 
interviewing techniques.

Basic knowledge of New Jersey State Lottery rules and regulations and State Laws pertaining to 
Lottery operations.

Basic knowledge of computer generated listings.

Considerable knowledge of court procedures involving testimony, introduction of evidence, and 
demeanor as a witness.

Considerable knowledge of applicable laws governing the conduct of investigations.

Ability to organize assigned field work, analyze investigative problems, and develop effective work 
methods.

Ability to analyze problems and apply State laws and regulations to Lottery operations.

Ability to plan, organize, conduct and supervise investigations of a general or specialized nature.

Ability to work cooperatively with associates, superiors, and State and local law enforcement 
agencies.

Ability to prepare clear, sound, accurate and informative reports containing findings, conclusions 
and recommendations.

Ability to prepare detailed correspondence.

Ability to read and understand computer print outs and use such print outs to aid investigations.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English sufficiently to perform the 
duties of this position. American Sign Language or braille may also be considered as acceptable 
forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can perform the essential 
functions of the job after reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the 
accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such 
persons may not be eligible.



This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote52344SUNE19N/AP19-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 7/13/84

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelor's degree.

alternativeQualifications: One year of experience as a member of a civil or military law enforcement or investigative agency performing field investigations

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for the Special Investigator, State Lottery position, as stated in the job specification. While a Bachelor's degree is listed as a requirement, it also allows for the substitution of this education requirement with relevant experience on a year-for-year basis. Therefore, if applicants possess sufficient experience in a civil or military law enforcement or investigative agency performing field investigations, they might still qualify for the position without a higher educational degree.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointee will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The primary barrier stated in the job description to hiring an applicant who does not have a college or university degree is the requirement for a Bachelor's degree. However, this education requirement can be substituted on a year-for-year basis with experience, specifically as a member of a civil or military law enforcement or investigative agency performing field investigations.

name: Associate Director Student Loan Programs
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR, STUDENT LOAN PROGRAMS

DEFINITION

Under the general supervision of the Director, Student Loan Programs, is responsible for the
overall administration and supervision of the various loan programs established by the legislature
 in accord with policies prescribed by the New Jersey Higher Education Assistance Authority. The
primary responsibility is the perpetuation of the programs through the solution of problems arising 
from time to time, and to act with full and complete authority on any issue during the absence of the 
Director; does related work as required.

EXAMPLES OF WORK

Coordinates and evaluates all staff work in meeting overall objectives of the Student Loan Office 
and Department as a whole.

Has primary responsibility for fiscal planning and for developing a program of fiscal accountability 
for the Student Loan Office.

Develops and maintains rapport with the financial community, i.e. commercial and savings banks, 
savings and loan associations, and credit unions in order to foster a good working relationship for 
the continuance of the Student Loan Program.

Develops and maintains rapport with all post-secondary educational institutions to promote their 
cooperation and compliance with regulations of the NJHEAA.

Develops overall personnel policy and administers staffing needs of the Student Loan Office.

Provides supervision and training to the Assistant Directors and other staff specialists in the office.

Develops and maintains program to provide information to the public by scheduling and speaking 
to high school students, parents, counselors and college financial aid officers. 

Supervises the work operations and/or functional programs and has responsibility for employee 
evaluations and for effectively recommending the hiring, firing, promoting, demoting and/or 
disciplining of employees.

Provides for the proper training of student loan officers throughout the State primarily through 
seminars at banks or savings and loan associations.

Directs research on substantive questions, identifying alternative courses of action, and 
coordinating resource requirements.

Within the policies of the Department of Higher Education and the regulations of the NJEAA, 
responsible for program review and qualitative program improvement through evaluation of current 
program.

Interprets State and federal legislation for application to Student Loan Program.

Implements necessary changes to program caused by modification to federal and/or Authority 
policy.

Provides for the preparation, design and distribution of a manual of procedures for lending 
institutions and schools, brochures, applications and note forms which are in keeping with both 
federal, and State laws and regulations.

Develops and maintains a good working relationship with the Attorney Generalï¿½s office to provide 
for the continuous support of all matters require legal attention.

Develops and maintains a good working relationship with State and federal law enforcement 
officials.

May be required to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and 
information systems used by the agency, office or related units. 

REQUIREMENTS

EDUCATION

Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelorï¿½s degree.

EXPERIENCE

Five years of professional experience in business or education in the area of student financial aid, 
counseling or professional experience in a financial institution such as a bank or savings and loan 
association or any combination thereof.

LICENSE

Appointee will be required to possess a driverï¿½s license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of 
a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES

Ability to read, understand and interpret State and federal legislation and regulations.

Ability to interpret program to the financial and educational communities in such a way as to 
effectively promote active participation in the program.

Ability to speak to various groups on different levels about the program benefits and procedures, 
i.e. school personnel, students, lenders and the public at large.

Ability to communicate orally and in written form with concerned parties, i.e. students, parents, 
lawyers, school and college officials, bank officials, State and federal government officials.

Ability to oversee enforcement of personnel policies and general supervision of employees so as 
to achieve maximum performance. 

Ability to encourage employees to improve skills and abilities, including the recommendation of 
educational programs, in order to assist them in developing their full potential.

Ability to manage the overall operation of the Student Loan Office so as to achieve maximum 
efficiency. 

Knowledge of the various types of educational institutions and their accrediting bodies.

Knowledge of the various types of financial institutions and their regulatory bodies.

Knowledge of State and federal budgeting process.

Ability to conduct research on substantive questions and to recommend policy changes.

Ability to learn to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording and information 
systems used by the agency, office or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in English sufficiently to perform the 
duties of this position. American Sign Language or braille may also be considered as acceptable 
forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible as long as they can perform the essential 
functions of the job after reasonable accommodation is made to their known limitations. If the 
accommodation cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such 
persons may not be eligible.

This job specification is applicable to the following title code:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote80219SUNL30N/AMD30-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 7/30/86

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelorâs degree.

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for this job as the qualification required is a Bachelor's degree, which is a standard level for many professional roles, not considered "higher" in the sense of requiring a graduate or advanced degree. The job emphasizes experience over advanced academic qualifications, requiring five years of professional experience in business or education related to student financial aid or within a financial institution, indicating that practical experience is more critical.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointee will be required to possess a driverâs license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform the essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description explicitly requires "Graduation from an accredited college with a Bachelorâs degree," which is a barrier to hiring an applicant who does not have a college or university degree.

name: Secretarial Assistant 1
text:
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification


SECRETARIAL ASSISTANT 1, NON-STENOGRAPHIC

DEFINITION:

Under supervision, provides secretarial, administrative and clerical support to an 
assigned assistant division director, bureau chief, or organizational equivalent; types 
correspondence and reports, prepares letters on routine matters, provides requested 
information to internal and external customers, maintains a schedule of appointments 
and the daily engagement calendar of the executive official; utilizes various information 
systems for daily work assignments used by the agency, office, or related units; does 
other related duties as required.

NOTE:  The examples of work for this title are for illustrative purposes only.  A 
particular position using this title may not perform all duties listed in this job 
specification.  Conversely, all duties performed on the job may not be listed.

NOTE:  Appointments may be made to positions requiring bilingual skills.

12505C - Bilingual in Spanish and English
SPECIAL SKILL
Applicants must be able to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in Spanish 
and English sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.

24531C - Bilingual in Spanish and English
SPECIAL SKILL
Applicants must be able to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in Spanish 
and English sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.

24531G - Bilingual in Spanish and English
SPECIAL SKILL
Applicants must be able to read, write, speak, understand, or communicate in Spanish 
and English sufficiently to perform the duties of this position.

EXAMPLES OF WORK:

Organizes assigned secretarial and administrative clerical work and develops effective 
work methods.

Types correspondence, reports, and recommendations of a confidential nature.

Reviews, sorts, and routes incoming correspondence.

Prepares letters on routine matters which may or may not be reviewed or signed by 
the executive official.

Obtains pertinent material from files and/or other sources; puts it into usable form 
for the review and use of the executive official.

Provides requested information to division personnel, representatives of state, local, 
and other groups, organizations, and agencies, and to the public in accordance with 
established policy.

May interview callers at the office.

Maintains a schedule of appointments and the daily engagement calendar of the 
executive official.

Prepares meeting agendas; types meeting minutes from notes or recording equipment.

Make arrangements for speaking engagements, travel, and for meetings, conferences, 
and hearings.

Maintains mailing lists and makes necessary revisions.

Prepares statistical and other reports.

Maintains confidential personal correspondence and other records and files, including 
a follow-up file.

Will be required to learn how to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual 
recording and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

REQUIREMENTS:

EXPERIENCE:

Three (3) years of experience in secretarial and administrative clerical work.

NOTE:  Successful completion of a clerical training program with a minimum of 700 
classroom training hours or thirty (30) semester hour credits in secretarial science from 
an accredited college or university may be substituted for one (1) year of the experience 
indicated above. Course work must include typing skills, methods, and procedures; other 
courses may include, but not be limited to, office procedures, word processing, and 
business English.

LICENSE:

Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the 
operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform essential 
duties of the position.

KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES:

Knowledge of secretarial, clerical, and other office routines, procedures, and practices, 
and their application to specific situations.

Knowledge of basic computer applications.

Knowledge of commonly used data processing and office applications.

Ability to read and interpret department regulations, programs, standards, and 
procedures.

Ability to accurately type correspondence and reports.

Ability to act as confidential secretary to an executive official.

Ability to organize secretarial work, sometimes of a confidential nature.

Ability to use correct English, to spell correctly, and to use correct sentence and 
paragraph structure.

Ability to communicate with visitors, schedule appointments, and process requests 
for information in accordance with established procedures.

Ability to prepare statistical and other reports.

Ability to prepare correspondence.

Ability to multitask.

Ability to learn, understand, and readily adapt to the computer systems used by 
the agency.

Ability to create mail merges, PowerPoint presentations for daily assignments.

Ability to maintain confidential, follow-up, and other records and files.

Ability to learn how to utilize various types of electronic and/or manual recording 
and information systems used by the agency, office, or related units.

Ability to read, write, speak, understand, and communicate in English sufficiently 
to perform the duties of this position.  American Sign Language or Braille may also 
be considered as acceptable forms of communication.

Persons with mental or physical disabilities are eligible if they can perform essential 
functions of the job with or without reasonable accommodation.  If the accommodation 
cannot be made because it would cause the employer undue hardship, such persons 
may not be eligible.


This job specification is applicable to the following title code(s) whichare different work week or work month and/or variants of the job class title:JobSpecCodeVariantState,Local orCommonClass ofServiceWorkWeekStateClassCodeLocalClassCodeSalaryRangeNote12505CNon StenographicSC4016N/AA17-24531CNon-StenographicSC3516N/AA15-24531GNon-Steno/Bilingual In Spanish & EngSC3516N/AA15-This job specification is for state government use only.Salary range is only applicable to state government.Local salaries are established by individual local jurisdictions. 11/21/2020

educationRequirements.evidenceQuote: thirty (30) semester hour credits in secretarial science from an accredited college or university may be substituted for one (1) year of the experience indicated above.

alternativeQualifications: Three (3) years of experience in secretarial and administrative clerical work

mandatoryStatusExplanations.degreeRequirementExplanation: A higher educational degree is not absolutely required for the job of Secretarial Assistant 1, Non-Stenographic. The job requires three years of experience in secretarial and administrative clerical work and does allow for the substitution of a clerical training program or college credits in secretarial science for one year of experience. This suggests that practical experience and specific skills are more critical for this role than holding a higher educational degree.

professionalLicenseRequirement.licenseDescription: Appointees will be required to possess a driver's license valid in New Jersey only if the operation of a vehicle, rather than employee mobility, is necessary to perform essential duties of the position.

degreeAnalysis.barriersToNonDegreeApplicants: The job description does not explicitly require a college or university degree. It does, however, allow for the substitution of experience with educational coursework. Specifically, the completion of 30 semester hour credits in secretarial science at an accredited college or university, including specific coursework, can substitute for one year of required experience. This suggests that while a degree is not mandatory, higher education can be used to offset a portion of the required experience, which could be a potential advantage for applicants with a college background. However, ultimately, the requirement is for experience, which doesn't inherently exclude those without a degree.

name: Senior Probation Officer
text:
.style2
        {
            font-size: small;
            font-weight: bold;
        }
    





  
You are reading the State of New Jersey Job Descriptions. This is not a Job Vacancy Announcement.
Job Specification
    
    

    
        
            
                
                    JUDICIARY OF THE STATE OF NEW JERSEY
                
               Case Processing Band Specification 
BAND SUMMARY 
A position in the Judiciary Case Processing Band Probation Officer Track conducts pre-disposition investigations and prepares reports; collects court-ordered payments; monitors and enforces conditions of probation and/or court order; provides access to social services to assist in rehabilitation of law offenders; and/or makes recommendations for alternate dispute resolution, adjudication, rehabilitation planning and treatment of offenders, including conditional release, substance abuse treatment, and education and employment stipulations. This track is used to classify positions in the vicinage Probation, Family, and Criminal Divisions. 
LEVEL SUMMARY 
Level 1 - Trainee/Investigator (Investigator): Employees at this level conduct interviews and perform investigatory work including initial case work-up and data entry in support of pre- and post-dispositional functions, complaints, allegations, enforcement activities, and other court services. Prepare reports for the court, monitor case flow, and provide case information to requesters. In Child Support Enforcement, manage a caseload requiring minimal follow up.
Level 2 - Basic (Probation Officer): Employees at this level perform case management functions, pre-disposition and intake functions, and prepare reports for the court. Monitor and enforce conditions of probation and/or court orders. Refer clients to treatment programs, therapeutic or rehabilitative placements, and arrange referrals to appropriate agencies. Make recommendations to the court.
Level 3 - Journey (Senior Probation Officer): Employees at this level perform case management functions and prepare reports for the court. Direct the activities of the probationer of a higher level complex case type. Refer clients to treatment programs, therapeutic or rehabilitative placements, and arrange referrals to appropriate agencies. Handle higher level complex responsibilities in addition to assigned caseload. Make recommendations to the court. May advise staff or team members with work in progress and/or train staff.
Level 4 - Mastery (Master Probation Officer): Employees at this level perform case management functions, and prepare reports for the court. Direct the activities of the probationer at a higher level complex case type. Refer clients to treatment programs, therapeutic or rehabilitative placements, and arrange referrals to appropriate agencies. Handle higher level complex responsibilities in addition to assigned caseload. Make recommendations to the court. Assigned to act as mentor or lead worker, provide technical advice and expertise, and/or as act as a subject matter expert.
NOTE: The above summary and following examples of work are for illustrative purposes only. Any one position may not include all of the tasks listed, nor do the examples cover all of the duties, which may be performed. Tasks are cumulative; higher levels include the tasks associated with lower. 
TASKS 
Level 1 
Annotate calendars with additional information required by judges
Answer questions posed by judges, the public, clients, customers, complainants, co-workers, subordinates or supervisors
Collect and/or maintain case statistics or financial data to generate status reports
Compile records or other written materials
Compose routine correspondence, such as form letters or standard replies to inquires
Conduct investigations
Determine status of complaints in accordance with established procedures or regulations
Explain judiciary policies or procedures to clients or customers
Gather relevant facts pertaining to cases
Greet customers, clients or visitors
Inform managers about clients'/customers' work progress or related matters
Interview clients or customers for needed information and document acquired information
Interview complainants and document acquired information
Investigate clients' or customers' personal or criminal history
Maintain records, files, or other written materials
Monitor casework flow
Monitor clients' or customers' payment pattern of court ordered payments
Monitor location of clients or customer 
Operate electronic or manual information systems
Participate in team/work unit meetings
Prepare investigative fact-finding reports
Provide information to judges, attorneys, or community organizations
Provide quality customer service to court users and/or internal customers
Provide cross-training to co-workers; for example, demonstrate to other staff how you perform your work
Review clients' or customers' records
Review documents submitted to the court for compliance with court rules and approved practices
Schedule meetings, appointments, interviews and other activities necessary for accomplishing job assignments 
Verify addresses, employment, or community contacts of prospective probationers, program participants or obliges
Verify authenticity or validity of documents
Verify clients' or customers' eligibility for assistance
Verify clients' or customers' information
Verify entered data against source documents
Write case notes or draft other case related correspondence
Level 2 
Act as a liaison and/or establish working relationships with divisions, vicinages or other outside organizations
Adhere to statutes, court rules, case law, manuals or policies for cases related to clients or customers
Advise judges, management or members of a tribunal on case issues
Advise the families or guardians of clients or customers on court processes or procedures
Analyze case histories
Analyze case processing and/or bail from intake through disposition
Analyze cases in accordance with existing laws, regulations or professional practices
Approve continuances or adjournments in adherence to state or local division rules or practices
Arrange for clients' or customers' admission or discharge into/from facilities
Arrange for clients' or customers' enrollment into training or educational programs
Arrange psychological testing of clients or customers
Assemble case files, documents or exhibits for hearings, trials or board meetings
Check written reports for completeness and accuracy
Collect court-ordered payments
Collect samples or specimens to test for alcohol or substance abuse
Complete subpoenas, writs, or other related legal documents
Conduct consent conferences for parents, guardians, and extended family members on such issues as child support, custody, or visitation rights
Conduct home visits
Conduct pre-court conferences
Confer with members of a case management team for program or case management
Consult with clients' or customers' treatment team
Coordinate activities between or among agencies or other government or enforcement units
Coordinate attorney's availability or readiness for hearings, trials and other court events
Determine the existence of a crisis situation for a client, customer and/or defendant requiring professional intervention
Develop treatment, including drug treatment, plans for clients or customers through community contacts
Discuss marital or other relationship problems and available resources with clients or customers
Discuss substance abuse issues with clients or customers
Draft correspondence, reports or proposals
Examine transcripts, case files, records or other materials to determine issues or sufficiency of evidence for certification
Explain conditions of program, probation or community service
Identify clients' or customers' case management needs or areas of concern
Inform clients or customers of available agency support programs or services
Inform litigants on the procedures related to case management
Interpret accounting, financial or statistical data 
Maintain department issued equipment and/or assigned fleet vehicle
Manage case flow and/or monitor outcomes 
May place electronic monitoring devices on clients/customers in accordance with state law and department policy
Monitor clients' or customers' treatment progress
Monitor terms of services and/or conditions in compliance with court orders
Obtain affidavits, evidence or other materials for hearings or trials
Present facts of case at hearings or court proceedings
Oversee progress of adult or juvenile offenders in complying with court ordered terms of probation or program and in counseling recommendations
Prepare cases for hearing
Prepare court orders
Prepare report of findings from legal research
Prepare technical, statistical, financial, review or evaluation reports 
Prepare trial notices or calendars
Prioritize cases
Provide guidance to clients or customers with personal problems or specific needs, for example, social, emotional, financial, vocational, rehabilitative
Provide guidance to the families or guardians of clients or customers, including recommendation of treatment programs and counseling alternatives
Provide testimony as an officer of the courts
Recommend alternative living arrangements for juvenile or adult clients or customers
Recommend appropriate court orders for submission to the courts
Recommend cases to court for adjudication or other dispute resolution mechanism
Recommend enforcement of federal, state, county or local laws according to client's compliance to terms of probation or program
Recommend improvements in operating procedures, programs, standards, work processes, or administrative practices 
Recommend incarceration of violators of probation or program
Recommend procedures to ensure compliance with court orders
Recommend social service agencies or community organizations to clients or customers
Recommend strategies for case progression and meeting case management goals
Recommend therapeutic or rehabilitative placements
Recommend treatment, including drug treatment, programs for clients or customers through community contacts
Refer clients to treatment programs based on compliance with terms of probation or program
Refer individuals to appropriate federal, state, county or local agencies
Respond to attorney, litigant or citizen complaints
Review case status with judges, managers or supervisors
Review clients' or customers' probation, program or community service violations
Review court activities for compliance with procedures, laws, court rules, or administrative directives
Review financial information in accordance with policies and procedures and/or system and auditing requirements
Review trial or other calendars for appropriate calendar balance
Review trial or other calendars for completeness or accuracy
Screen and assign cases to appropriate track or event
Summarize dispositions, interrogatories or testimony for review by others
Write reports for the court on which judicial determinations will be based
Level 3 
Apply statutes, court rules, case law, policies, or other regulatory standards to cases
Conduct financial audits for accuracy, compliance or legitimacy following standards to maintain security or confidentiality
Coordinate work activities of unit or team members
Determine clients' or customers' treatment objectives
Direct and/or coordinate work between units or teams 
Discuss specialized treatment or supervision with adult and/or juvenile clients or customers as needed
Evaluate clients or customers with more complex or chronic problems
Facilitate crisis intervention counseling
Facilitate group counseling sessions
Facilitate individual counseling sessions 
Give advice or assist staff or team members with work in progress
Identify barriers to successful completion of program and develop potential solutions
Identify intervention points and develop strategies for resolution
Participate in the development of operational programs, procedures, practices and standards
Provide structured training to co-workers
Serve on committee(s) or task force(s) 
Level 4 
Act as lead worker to team members or other group of non- subordinates in assigned tasks
Design case management processes
Evaluate case management systems to offer suggestions or solutions to existing problems
Mentor and coach clients or customers
Mentor and coach staff; provide direction and feedback
Provide higher level technical advice and/or expertise to staff, peers or management
Resolve disputes, conflicts or problems regarding programs or services
COMPETENCIES
NOTE: The following competencies are cumulative in nature. For example, lower level competencies are prerequisite to higher levels.
Level 1 
Attention To Detail - Thorough when performing work and conscientious about attending to detail.
Customer Service - Committed to providing quality services. Works with clients and customers to assess their needs, provide information or assistance, resolve their problems, or satisfy their expectations. Knows about available products and services.
Flexibility - Open to change and new information. Adapts behavior or work methods in response to new information, changing conditions, or unexpected obstacles.
Information Management - Identifies a need for and knows where and how to gather information. Organizes and maintains information or information management systems.
Integrity and Honesty - Contributes to maintaining the integrity of the organization. Displays high standards of ethical conduct and understands the organization’s standards, including confidentiality in court operations, when appropriate, and the impact of violating these standards on an organization, self, and others. Trustworthy.
Interpersonal Skills - Shows understanding, respect, collegiality, courtesy, tact, empathy, cooperation, concern, and politeness to others. Develops and maintains effective relationships with others which may include effectively dealing with individuals who are difficult, hostile, or distressed. Relates well with people from varied backgrounds and different situations. Sensitive to cultural diversity, race, gender, disabilities, and other individual differences. Participates fully in team activities. Models pro-social behavior in interactions with participants.
Knowledge Retention - Recalls information that has been presented previously.
Oral Communication –Effectively communicates information, for example, ideas or facts, to individuals or groups effectively, taking into account the audience and nature of the information, for example, technical, sensitive, or controversial. Makes clear and convincing oral presentations. Listens to others, attends to nonverbal cues, and responds appropriately.
Organizational Awareness - Knows the organization’s mission and functions, and how its social, political, and technological systems work and operates effectively within them, including the programs, policies, procedures, rules, and regulations of the organization.
Perceptual Speed - Quickly and accurately sees detail in words, numbers, pictures, and graphs.
Public Safety and Security - Knowledgeable of investigation and inspection techniques and the rules, regulations, precautions, and prevention techniques for the protection of people, data, and property.
Reading Comprehension - Understands and interprets written material, including technical material, rules, regulations, instructions, reports, charts, graphs or tables. Applies what is learned from written material to specific situations.
Self-Management - Sets well-defined and realistic personal goals. Displays a high level of initiative, effort, and commitment towards completing assignments in a timely manner. Works with minimal supervision. Motivated to achieve. Demonstrates responsible behavior.
Team Work - Encourages and facilitates cooperation, pride, trust, and group identity. Fosters commitment and team spirit. Works with others to achieve goals.
Technology Application - Uses machines, tools, or equipment effectively. Uses computers and computer applications to analyze and communicate information in the appropriate format.
Written Communication - Composes correspondence, reports and other written material that is clear, concise, well organized and understood by recipient. Recognizes and uses correct English grammar, punctuation, and spelling. Communicates information, for example, facts, ideas, or messages, in a succinct and organized manner. Produces written information, which may include technical material which is appropriate for the intended audience.
Level 2 
Economics and Accounting - Knowledgeable of economic and accounting principles and practices, with technical competence in credit and collections.
Legal, Government, and Jurisprudence –Knowledgeable of laws, legal codes, legal documents, court procedures, precedents, legal practices, government regulations, executive orders, agency rules, and government organization and functions. This generally includes court rules, practices and procedures, and rules of evidence.
Mathematical Reasoning - Performs computations, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication and division correctly using whole numbers, fractions, decimals and percentages. Solves practical problems by applying a variety of mathematical and statistical techniques.
Problem Solving - Identifies problems. Determines accuracy and relevance of information. Uses sound judgment to generate and evaluate alternatives, and to make recommendations.
Psychology - Knowledgeable of human behavior and performance in various contexts, mental processes, or the assessment and treatment of behavioral and affective disorders. Maintains the boundaries of the dual role relationship, for example supervision and rehabilitation.
